revision.comment: Added reference to the involvement of a coroner's jury in the aftermath of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire, as an additional example of coroners' juries in the U.S.
revision.text:
A '''coroner's jury''' is a body convened to assist a [[coroner]] in an [[inquest]], that is, in determining the identity of a deceased person and the cause of death. The laws on its role and function vary by jurisdiction.
==United Kingdom== {{main|Inquests in England and Wales}}
In the United Kingdom, all inquests were once conducted with a [[jury]]. They acted somewhat like a [[grand jury]], determining whether a person should be committed to trial in connection to a death. Such a jury was made up of up to twenty-three men, and required the votes of twelve to render a decision. Similar to a grand jury, a Coroner's Jury merely accused, it did not [[convict]].
Since 1927, Coroner's Juries have rarely been used in England. Under the ''Coroners Act, 1988'',<ref>[http://www.bailii.org/uk/legis/num_act/ca1988120/s8.html Coroners Act, 1988, s 8(3)]</ref> a Jury is only required to be convened in cases where the death occurred in prison, police custody, or in circumstances which may affect public health or safety. The coroner can actually choose to convene a jury in any investigation, but in practice this is rare. The qualifications to sit on a Coroner's Jury are the same as those to sit on a jury in [[Crown Court]], the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]], and the [[county court]]s.<ref name="kcl">{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/depsta/law/research/coroners/jury.html|title=King's College of London - Coroner's Law Resource}}</ref>
Additionally, a Coroner's Jury only determines cause of death, its ruling does not commit a person to trial. While grand juries, which did have the power to indict, were abolished in the United Kingdom by 1948 (after being effectively stopped in 1933), Coroner's Juries retained those powers until the [[Criminal Law Act 1977]]. This change came about after [[Richard Bingham, 7th Earl of Lucan|Lord Lucan]] was charged in 1975 by a Coroner's Jury in the death of Sandra Rivett, his children's nanny.<ref name="kcl" />
==United States== A coroner's jury deemed [[Wyatt Earp]], [[Doc Holliday]], and their [[wikt:posse#Noun|posse]] guilty in the death of [[Frank Stilwell]] in March 1882 (See [http://members.tripod.com/~Tombstonehistory/wefs.html]).
In the aftermath of the [[Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire]], a coroner's jury found factory owners Isaac Harris and Max Blanck responsible for the death of Mary Herman, a factory operator.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/?a=d&d=MP19110418.2.12&e=-------en--20--1--txt-txIN--------1|title=Morning Press 18 April 1911 — California Digital Newspaper Collection|website=cdnc.ucr.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060502015746/http://www.courtsni.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/27EBDF24-84C3-4D5F-A354-2BBDB1511C63/0/p_ucs_coronersjuryservice.pdf Scan of a standard pamphlet] sent those called to serve on a Corner's Jury in Northern Ireland *[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/depsta/law/research/coroners/noterup.html Jarvis on Coroners] *[http://www.omnux.com/kvandivo/jury/ Writeup explaining concepts and example cases of a Coroner's Jury]
{{Jury}} [[Category:Judiciaries]] [[Category:Criminology]] [[Category:Wills and trusts]] [[Category:Coroner's courts]] [[Category:Juries]]
{{law-term-stub}}

'''Conrad Henri Roy III''' (September 12, 1995 {{ndash}} July 13, 2014) was an American [[marine salvage]] captain. His suicide at the age of 18 with encouragement from his long-distance girlfriend, 17-year-old Michelle Carter, was the subject of a noted investigation and [[involuntary manslaughter]] trial in [[Massachusetts]], popularly known as the "'''texting suicide case'''". The case, ''Commonwealth v. Michelle Carter'', involved many text messages, emails, and phone calls between Carter and Roy at the time of Roy's death. Roy had seen numerous [[mental health professional]]s and insisted he wanted to die. They had both been prescribed psychiatric medication. The case raised complex questions about [[criminal responsibility]].{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/crime/michelle-carter-and-conrad-roy-text-messages-trial-begins/|title=5 Things to Know: The Teen Girl Who Allegedly Urged Her Boyfriend to Kill Himself Via Texts|date=2017-06-06|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2017-06-13|language=en-US}} Carter was convicted by a judge of involuntary manslaughter, who stated this was due specifically to a final text in which Carter told Roy to get back in his truck when he became scared. == Roy's early life and career == Roy was born in 1995 in [[Mattapoisett, Massachusetts]]. He was sometimes socially anxious attending school and going into the classroom. For many years he worked with his father, grandfather, and uncle in his family's [[marine salvage]] business, Tucker-Roy Marine Towing and Salvage, Inc. in the New England area. In the Spring of 2014 he earned his [[United States Coast Guard Charter Boat Captain's license|captain's license]] from the Northeast Maritime Institute by completing three months of night classes.{{Cite news|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/20150228/NEWS/150229439|title=Court filing reopens wound for family of Conrad Roy III|last=mlawrence@s-t.com|first=Mike Lawrence|work=southcoasttoday.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}} In June 2014 he graduated on the [[Honors student|Honor Roll]] (highest grades) from [[Old Rochester Regional High School]] (ORR) in Mattapoisett. He was an all-around high school athlete who played baseball, rowed crew, and ran track. He graduated with a 3.88 GPA and had been accepted to Fitchburg State University to study business, but at that point had decided not to go.{{Cite news|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/06/michelle_carter_trial_conrad_r.html|title=Michelle Carter trial: Conrad Roy's mother chokes up while testifying about last day they spent together|work=masslive.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US}} Roy struggled with [[social anxiety]] and [[Depression (mood)|depression]] for which he had seen several therapists and counselors, including a [[Cognitive behavioral therapy|cognitive behavioral therapist]] in the weeks prior to his death. He had been hospitalized for an [[acetaminophen]] (paracetamol) overdose at the age of 17; he was talking to a girl he had met in a group and she called the police.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2016/02/conrad-roy-michelle-carter-c-v-r.html|title=Does Encouraging Suicide Make You a Killer?|date=2016-03-01|work=The Cut|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}} == Roy's death == On Sunday, July 13, 2014, following digital exchanges with Carter while interacting with his family, Roy committed [[suicide]] by poisoning himself with [[carbon monoxide]] fumes in his truck in the now-closed [[Kmart]] parking lot in [[Fairhaven, Massachusetts]]. Carter attended a different high school, [[King Philip Regional High School]], in [[Wrentham, Massachusetts]]. They had met on family vacation in Florida several years prior and had maintained on-off communication, meeting only a few times. Roy's [[Funeral|Memorial Mass]] was celebrated on Saturday, July 19, 2014, at St. Anthony's Church in [[Mattapoisett]]. The Captain Conrad H. Roy III Scholarship Fund at the Northeast Maritime Institute in [[Fairhaven, Massachusetts]], was established in his memory.[http://www.tributes.com/obituary/show/Conrad-Henri-Roy-101530417 Obituary for Conrad Henri Roy III] == Court proceedings == {{Infobox court case |name = Commonwealth v. Michelle Carter |court = [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ]] |image = |imagesize = |imagelink = |imagealt = |caption = |full name = |date decided = {{start date|2017|06|16}} |citations = No. 15YO0001NE |ECLI = |transcripts = |judges = [[Lawrence Moniz]]
([[Bristol County Juvenile Court]]) |number of judges = 1 |decision by = |concurring = |dissenting = |concur/dissent = |prior actions = |appealed from = |appealed to = |subsequent actions = |related actions = |opinions = |keywords = |italic title = no }} Michelle Carter was [[Indictment|indicted]] on February 4, 2015, and [[Arraignment|arraigned]] the following day at in [[New Bedford, Massachusetts|New Bedford]] [[Juvenile court|Juvenile Court]] on charges of [[involuntary manslaughter]] in [[Taunton, Massachusetts]]. The [[grand jury]] found enough to charge her with "wantonly and recklessly" assisting the suicide. She was 17 at the time and the court indicted her as a 'youthful offender' rather than a 'juvenile', meaning she could be sentenced as if an adult.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2015/02/27/plainville-teen-charged-with-manslaughter-friend-suicide/WM5yHKA5IpobG2WXEWHLFM/story.html|title=Plainville teen charged with manslaughter in friend’s suicide - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2017-06-26}} In May 2015, Roy's family were upset by pictures posted on social media by Gail Carter, despite a court order, showing her daughter Michelle in a [[prom]] dress and on a trip to Orlando taking part in a [[DECA (organization)|DECA]] schools competition which included visiting [[Walt Disney World]].[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3102466/Teen-faces-20-years-bars-encouraging-friend-kill-goes-Disney-World-prom-ahead-manslaughter-trial.html Warren, L. Teen who faces 20 years behind bars 'for encouraging friend to kill himself'] goes to [[Disney World]] and prom ahead of manslaughter trial. Daily Mail. Published: 08:39 EDT, 29 May 2015 | Updated: 21:01 EDT, 29 May 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/lists/trial-begins-for-teen-accused-of-urging-boyfriend-to-suicide-w485803|title=Trial Begins for Teen Accused of Urging Boyfriend to Suicide|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2017-06-26}} In June 2015 a district court judge denied a defense motion to remove the Bristol County District Attorney’s office from the prosecution because DA Thomas M. Quinn III is a third cousin of Conrad Roy and first cousin to Roy’s grandmother Janice Roy. Quinn had already handed the case over to his Deputy DA William McCauley.{{Cite news|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/20150604/NEWS/150609651|title=Bristol DA's office can continue to prosecute Michelle Carter case|last=cbrown@s-t.com|first=Curt Brown|work=southcoasttoday.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}} On July 1, 2016 an appeal heard by the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] was also denied, on the basis that there was probable cause, allowing the case to go forward.[https://www.boston.com/news/crime/2016/04/07/heres-what-mass-supreme-court-justices-asked-about-the-suicide-encouragement-case Manning, L. Here’s what Mass. Supreme Court justices asked about the suicide-encouragement case. Boston.com, April 7, 2016, Accessed June 15, 2017]{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/549d03a735e143f7b3c416b9e789a767/Court-OKs-trial-for-girl-who-texted-boyfriend-urging-suicide|title=Court OKs trial for girl who texted boyfriend urging suicide|work=AP News|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US}} The day before trial was due to start on June 6, 2017, Carter waived her right to jury trial and therefore the case was heard by Hon. Lawrence Moniz in the Bristol County Juvenile Court of Massachusetts, in [[Taunton, Massachusetts|Taunton]].{{Cite web|url=http://wwlp.com/2017/06/05/michelle-carter-waives-right-to-jury-trial-judge-will-decide-case/|title=Michelle Carter waives right to jury trial; judge will decide case|last=Krause|first=Nancy|last2=Machado|first2=Steph|date=2017-06-06|website=WWLP.com|access-date=2017-06-26|last3=WPRI}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/06/05/trial-starts-today-texting-suicide-case-involving-michelle-carter/S3citWceY4Zgz2VzgUR6cO/story.html|title=Judge, not jury, will decide texting suicide case|date=June 5, 2017|work=Boston Globe|last2=Ransom|first2=Jan|first1=John R.|last1=Ellement}} Carter was represented by Joseph P. Cataldo and Cory Madera.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-text-suicide-20170616-story.html|title=Michelle Carter found guilty in Massachusetts texting suicide case|date=June 16, 2017|publisher=Tribune Media|agency=LA Times|last1=Demick|first1=Barbara|accessdate=2018-01-11}} It is believed to be the first involuntary manslaughter trial in Massachusetts related to [[texting]] to encourage suicide [''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]''] though there have been a few related cases.{{cite web|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2016/03/five_facts_to_know_about_michelle_carter_plainfield_teen.html|title=Five facts to know about Michelle Carter, the Plainville teen accused of encouraging her boyfriend's suicide|publisher=|accessdate=June 13, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.forensicmag.com/news/2017/06/manslaughter-trial-begins-woman-accused-coercing-suicide-through-text-messages|title=Manslaughter Trial Begins for Woman Accused of Coercing Suicide through Text Messages|date=2017-06-06|work=Forensic Magazine|access-date=2017-06-26}} On June 16, 2017, Judge Lawrence Moniz of the Bristol County Juvenile Court of Massachusetts, in [[Taunton, Massachusetts|Taunton]] found Carter legally guilty of involuntary manslaughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-carter-text-suicide-trial-verdict-guilty/|title=Michelle Carter text suicide trial verdict: Guilty|publisher=CBSNews.com|accessdate=16 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/06/16/michelle-carter-guilty-suicide-testing-trial/To0pxezEP0hArZdX8k0DtN/story.html|title=Michelle Carter found guilty in texting suicide case|publisher=BostonGlobe.com|accessdate=16 June 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/16/us/michelle-carter-texting-case/index.html|title=Judge finds Michelle Carter guilty of manslaughter in texting suicide case|date=16 June 2017|publisher=Cable News Network/Turner Broadcasting|agency=CNN|last2=Lance|first2=Natisha|last1=Sanchez|first1=Ray|accessdate=16 June 2017}} He stated prior to his ruling that it was Carter's phone calls with Roy when he was in his truck gassing himself (as described by Carter's texts to friends), rather than the preceding text messages, that caused him to go through with killing himself.{{Cite news|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/06/michelle_carter_found_guilty_i.html|title=Michelle Carter found guilty by judge in text message suicide case|work=masslive.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US}} According to CNN, this decision "could set legal precedent for whether it's a crime to tell someone to commit suicide." Carter remained free on [[bail]][http://whdh.com/news/michelle-carter-found-guilty-of-manslaughter-in-texting-suicide-case/ Michelle Carter leaving court after manslaughter conviction: http://bit.ly/2sy32RW] until her sentencing on August 3 when she was sentenced to 2.5 years in prison for manslaughter, though she faced up to 20 years. In April 2016 Roy's mother Lynn reportedly said she was not sure what she wanted to happen to Carter, referring to an interaction between two unwell people and that Carter could have saved him.{{Cite news|url=https://www.boston.com/news/crime/2016/04/11/for-conrad-roys-mother-his-suicide-isnt-just-a-controversial-case|title=For Conrad Roy’s mother, his suicide isn’t just a controversial case|date=2016-04-11|work=Boston.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US}} After the guilty verdict Roy's father stated publicly that the family were pleased with the verdict but that they wanted privacy and time to process the events they have experienced; Lynn Roy appeared on the [[CBS]] '[[48 Hours (TV series)|48 Hours]]' show saying she didn't believe Carter had a conscience and that she knew exactly what she was doing.{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/crime/conrad-roy-parents-react-michelle-carter-manslaughter-verdict/|title=Teen’s Parents Speak Out on the Girlfriend Who Encouraged Their Son’s Suicide|date=2017-06-16|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US}} On August 3, 2017, Judge Lawrence Moniz sentenced Carter to serve a two-and-a-half-year term, with 15 months to be served in the Bristol County House of Corrections, the rest of the balance suspended, and five years of probation to be served.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/03/us/michelle-carter-texting-suicide-sentencing/index.html|title=Woman sentenced to 15 months in texting suicide case|last=CNN|first=Ray Sanchez, Natisha Lance and Eric Levenson and|website=CNN|access-date=2017-08-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.boston.com/news/local-news/2017/08/03/live-watch-michelle-carters-sentencing-in-texting-suicide-case|title=Michelle Carter sentenced in texting suicide case|date=2017-08-03|work=Boston.com|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en-US}} Soon after the sentencing was handed down, Carter's lawyers asked Judge Moniz to issue a stay of the sentence until all of Carter's Massachusetts court appeals options are exhausted. Judge Moniz granted the stay with conditions that Carter stay away from the Roy family.{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/08/03/michelle-carter-could-get-20-year-prison-term-at-thursday-sentencing.html|title=Michelle Carter, woman in suicide texting case, sentenced|last=Lam|first=Katherine|date=2017-08-03|work=Fox News|access-date=2017-08-03|language=en-US}} === Background === {{Infobox Criminal | subject_name = Michelle Carter | image_name = | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|08|11}} | birth_place = [[Plainville, Massachusetts]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | charge = | conviction = [[Manslaughter (United States law)#Involuntary manslaughter|Involuntary manslaughter]] | penalty = 2.5-years reduced to 15-months plus 5-years [[probation]] | status = Free while sentence is [[Appellate procedure in the United States|appealed]] | occupation = }} Michelle Carter and then 16-year-old Conrad Roy met one another in Florida in 2012 while each had been visiting relatives. After this initial encounter, they saw each other in person again only once or twice over the course of three years, despite having lived only about 35 miles (55 km) away from each other in the Boston suburbs.{{cite web|last1=La Miere|first1=Jason|title=WHO IS MICHELLE CARTER? VERDICT REACHED IN TEXTING SUICIDE TRIAL INVOLVING DEATH OF CONRAD ROY III|url=http://www.newsweek.com/michelle-carter-verdict-conrad-roy-626649|publisher=[[Newsweek]]|accessdate=6 August 2017|date=16 June 2017}} Instead, they mostly exchanged text messages and emails.[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/12/us/suicide-texting-manslaughter-teenagers.html Trial Over Suicide and Texting Lays Bare Pain of 2 Teenagers], [[New York Times]] Roy also made some videos of himself talking to camera, which formed an important part of the case.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/texting-trial-conrad-roy-suicide-videos-friend-michelle-carter-manslaughter-trial/|title=Videos of Conrad Roy now key evidence in texting suicide trial|access-date=2017-06-30|language=en}} Carter was born on August 11, 1996, in Massachusetts to Gail and David Carter. She went to [[King Philip Regional High School]], Wrentham. She had developed an [[Eating disorder|eating disorde]]r from the age 8 or 9, may have [[self-harm|injured herself]] by cutting,{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/crime/teen-accused-of-urging-boyfriends-suicide-took-meds-that-hurt-her-ability-to-empathize-psychiatrist/|title=Teen Accused of Urging Boyfriend’s Suicide Took Meds that Hurt Her Ability to Empathize: Psychiatrist|date=2017-06-12|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en-US}} was on prescription psychiatric medication from the age of 14, and attended [[Psychotherapy|counseling]] at [[McLean Hospital]] in [[Belmont, Massachusetts|Belmont]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/news/20170606/contrasting-views-of-evidence-in-michelle-carter-trial|title=Contrasting views of evidence in Michelle Carter trial|last=Brown|first=Curt|work=southcoasttoday.com|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2016/03/details_emerge_about_michelle.html|title=Details emerge about Michelle Carter, Plainville teen accused of encouraging boyfriend Conrad Roy to kill himself|work=masslive.com|access-date=2017-06-13|language=en-US}} According to court documents, Roy had allegedly been physically hit by his father and verbally abused by his grandfather, and tried to kill himself in October 2012 while despondent after his parents divorced.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thesunchronicle.com/news/local_news/judge-hears-two-different-portraits-of-plainville-woman-during-texting/article_24d9bf3d-1693-5870-ae5e-2f9db0da459a.html|title=Judge hears two different portraits of Plainville woman during texting-suicide trial|last=dlinton@thesunchronicle.com|first=David Linton|work=The Sun Chronicle|access-date=2017-06-28|language=en}} After learning that he was planning to kill himself, Carter repeatedly discouraged him from committing suicide in 2012 and 2014 and encouraged him to "get professional help". However, her attitude changed in July 2014, when she started thinking that it would be a "good thing to help him die". In June, Roy had texted Carter suggesting they act like [[Romeo and Juliet]], checking that she understood they had each killed themselves.{{Cite news|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/boston/index.ssf/2017/06/if_they_read_my_messages_to_hi.html|title=Michelle Carter trial: Was Conrad Roy 'Romeo' or a 'pawn?' Defense and prosecution clash in opening statements|work=masslive.com|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US}} Prosecutors claimed that Carter had sought public attention from her boyfriend's death, and their putative relationship was almost entirely online rather than in-person. The suggestibility and vulnerability of Roy, a minor at the time, has been an issue. Carter's defense lawyers argued that Roy had a history of suicide attempts and the decision to end his life was his own,{{cite news|url=https://www.boston.com/news/crime/2017/06/12/defense-michelle-carter-who-sent-texts-urging-suicide-was-a-very-troubled-youngster|title=Defense: Michelle Carter was a ‘very troubled youngster|date=16 June 2017|publisher=Boston Globe Media Partners|agency=Cosmopolitan|last1=Associated Press|accessdate=16 June 2017}} that Carter was "bewildered" over the case against her, and that, "Taking all the texts in context, she tried to talk him out of it... ."[http://www.thesunchronicle.com/news/local_news/lawyer-plainville-teen-bewildered-over-involuntary-manslaughter-charges-in-friend/article_ba5a8a3e-e9d9-11e4-b645-e7549f97c906.html Hand, J. Lawyer: Plainville teen ‘bewildered’ over involuntary manslaughter charges in friend’s suicide death. April 23, 2015, Accessed June 15, 2017] They argued in initial hearings that the defendant had broken no law and had been a [[First amendment rights|first amendment right]] to [[free speech]], and that at that time she was a [[Juvenile delinquency|juvenile]]. Roy had also been taking Celexa for some time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.boston.com/news/crime/2016/07/29/attorney-for-teen-accused-of-encouraging-boyfriend-to-kill-himself-raises-questions-about-antidepressant|title=Attorney for teen accused of encouraging boyfriend to kill himself raises questions about antidepressant|date=2016-07-29|work=Boston.com|access-date=2017-06-20|language=en-US}} In the United States, [[citalopram]] carries a [[boxed warning]] stating it may increase [[Suicidality|suicidal thinking and behavior]] in those under age 24. In 2016 the judge had refused the defense's request for funds to hire an expert on Celexa, describing it as 'speculative'.{{Cite news|url=https://thoughtcatalog.com/gabriel-tewksbury/2017/06/in-defense-of-michelle-carter-the-teenager-who-urged-her-boyfriend-to-kill-himself/|title=Michelle Carter Might Not Be The Only Thing Responsible For Conrad Roy’s Death|date=2017-06-09|work=Thought Catalog|access-date=2017-08-07|language=en-US}}{{cite web|url=http://www.frx.com/pi/celexa_pi.pdf|title=Celexa (citalopram hydrobromide) Tablets/Oral Solution|work=Prescribing Information|publisher=Forest Laboratories, Inc.|format=pdf}}{{Cite web|url=http://wpri.com/2016/12/01/judge-denies-funds-for-drug-expert-in-texting-suicide-case/|title=Judge denies funds for drug expert in texting suicide case|last=Press|first=The Associated|date=2016-12-01|website=WPRI 12 Eyewitness News|access-date=2017-08-07}} === Legal repercussions === The case is expected by some to set a [[legal precedent]].[http://www.bostonherald.com/news/columnists/bob_mcgovern/2017/06/mcgovern_michelle_carter_case_set_to_make_legal_history McGovern, R. Michelle Carter case set to make legal history.] "The ruling... may spur lawmakers to [[Criminal code|codify]] the behavior highlighted in the case as criminal."[http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/16/us/michelle-carter-texting-case/index.html Sanchez, R., Lance, N. Judge finds Michelle Carter guilty of manslaughter in texting suicide case. Updated 12:16 PM ET, Friday, June 16, 2017] The judge had noted that Carter had willed Roy's death, that she did not order him out of the truck and that her actions "put him in that toxic environment" which "constituted reckless conduct" and "that the conduct caused the death of Mr. Roy." In effect, her actions led to his death and that her complicity did not falter.[''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]''] While, per U.S. law, the lower-court decision cannot bind other courts,[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/16/us/suicide-texting-trial-michelle-carter-conrad-roy.html Seelye, K.Q., and Bidgoodjune, J. Michelle Carter Is Guilty of Manslaughter in Texting Suicide Case. Washington Post, June 16, 2017] legal professionals believe it could have a social effect by raising other courts' attention to new, digital methods of committing crimes.{{cite news|last1=Bever|first1=Lindsey|title=e Michelle Carter, who urged her boyfriend to commit suicide, found guilty in his death|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2017/06/16/shes-accused-of-pushing-him-to-suicide-now-a-judge-has-decided-her-fate/|accessdate=17 June 2017|agency=Washington Post|publisher=Fred Ryan|date=June 16, 2017}} The case also attempts to redefine the social spectrum and which attitudes and behaviors would qualify as criminal that were not considered criminal before. {{cite news|last1=Seelye|first1=Katharine Q.|title=Michelle Carter Is Guilty of Manslaughter in Texting Suicide Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/16/us/suicide-texting-trial-michelle-carter-conrad-roy.html?_r=0|accessdate=17 June 2017|agency=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=16 June 2017}} Carter was sentenced to 2.5 years (30 months) in prison but to serve 15 months (1.25 years). ==Media== On September 23, 2018, [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] released a TV film called ''[[Conrad & Michelle: If Words Could Kill]]'' which stars [[Austin P. McKenzie]] as Conrad Roy and [[Bella Thorne]] as Michelle Carter.{{cite news|last=Baty|first=Emma|title=Bella Thorne Will Play Michelle Carter in New Lifetime Movie About Conrad Roy III's Suicide|url=https://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/movies/a22843747/bella-thorne-michelle-carter-lifetime-movie/|publisher=Cosmopolitan|date=August 27, 2018|accessdate=September 25, 2018}} == See also == {{div col|colwidth=21em}} * [[Assisted suicide]] * [[Complicity]] * [[Internet suicide pact]] * [[Social media and suicide]] * [[Suicidality]] * [[Suicide of Megan Meier]] * [[William Francis Melchert-Dinkel]] * [[Suicide of Phoebe Prince]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.currentobituary.com/member/obit/143229 Obituary page for Captain Conrad H. Roy III, July 13, 2014] * [https://www.facebook.com/kings9126 'Remembering Conrad Roy' Facebook page] * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/276206526/Michelle-Carter-Texts Commonwealth's (New Bedford Juvenile Court) Response to Defendant's Motion to Dismiss, August 2015] * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/307260480/Michelle-Carter-Appellant-Brief Michelle Carter Appellant Brief, March 2016] * [http://law.justia.com/cases/massachusetts/supreme-court/2016/sjc-12043.html Supreme Court affirms decision, July 2016] * [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/06/16/us/document-Commonwealth-vs-Michelle-Carter.html Decision of Trial Judge, June 2017] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RyDR0lUTXzY 20/20 Documentary on ABC] * [https://www.cbsnews.com/video/death-by-text/ 48 Hours Documentary on CBS] * [https://www.doctoroz.com/episode/could-you-die-eating-too-much-protein?video_id=5591017819001 What Happened to Conrad Roy? on The Doctor Oz Show] * [http://abcnews.go.com/US/words-kill-guilty-verdict-texting-suicide-trial-raises/story?id=48093522 Can words kill? Guilty verdict in texting suicide trial raises questions] {{DEFAULTSORT:Roy, Conrad Henri}} [[Category:1995 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths by person]] [[Category:Male suicides]] [[Category:Manslaughter in the United States]] [[Category:Manslaughter victims]] [[Category:People from New Bedford, Massachusetts]] [[Category:People with mood disorders]] [[Category:Suicides in Massachusetts]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} '''Definitions of abortion''' vary from one source to another. [[Abortion]] has many definitions that can differ from each other in significant ways. Given the contentious nature of abortion, lawmakers and other stakeholders often face controversy in defining abortion.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Arzuaga|first=Bonnie Hope|author2=Lee, Ben Hokew |title=Limits of Human Viability in the United States: A Medicolegal Review.|journal=Pediatrics|date=December 2011|volume=128|issue=6|pages=1047–1052 |url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/128/6/1047.full |accessdate=24 November 2013 |doi=10.1542/peds.2011-1689 |pmid=22065266}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Morag‐Levine|first=Noga|title=Imported problem definitions, legal culture and the local dynamics of Israeli abortion politics|journal=Israel Affairs|year=1998|volume=5|issue=2-3 |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13537129908719520?journalCode=fisa20#.UpJxK9JwrOs |accessdate=24 November 2013 |doi=10.1080/13537129908719520}}</ref> Language referring to abortion often reflects societal and political [[Abortion debate|opinions]] (not only scientific knowledge).<ref name=oxfordbiblio>{{cite web | url=http://www.oxfordbibliographies.com/view/document/obo-9780199756797/obo-9780199756797-0090.xml?rskey=tygpVh&result=1 | title=Abortion | publisher=[[Oxford Bibliographies]] | accessdate=9 April 2014 | author=Kulczycki, Andrzej}}</ref> Influential non-state actors like the United Nations<ref>{{cite news|last=Hale|first=Ellen|title=Definitions slow debate on abortions|date=9 September 1994|newspaper=USA Today|page=1A}}<!--|accessdate=3 January 2013--></ref> and the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic Church]] have also engendered controversy over efforts to define abortion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Defining the undefined key in abortion debate. The Catholic Church's position on the difference between direct and indirect abortion is considered by Joe Foyle|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=31 July 2000|page=14}}<!--|accessdate=3 January 2013--></ref> [[Late termination of pregnancy]] is the term usually used for later uterine evacuation.<ref name=Grimes>{{cite web | url=http://www.contraceptionjournal.org/article/PIIS0010782409004156/fulltext | title=Abortion jabberwocky: the need for better terminology | publisher=Contraception Journal | date=February 2010 | accessdate=9 April 2014 |author1=Grimes, David A. |author2=Gretchen, Stuart | pages=93–96 | volume=81 | issue=2 | DOI= 10.1016/j.contraception.2009.09.005}}</ref>
==Concerns in the medical community== Ambiguous definitions can create concerns in the medical community.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roe|first=K.M.|title=Private troubles and public issues: providing abortion amid competing definitions|journal=Social Science & Medicine|year=1989|volume=29|issue=10 |pages=1191–8 |doi=10.1016/0277-9536(89)90362-6 |pmid=2588046}}</ref> Physicians in several countries, including Ireland<ref>{{cite news|last=Coulter|first=Carol|title=Legislation to clarify abortion issue advised |date=4 July 1996|page=7}}<!--|accessdate=3 January 2013--></ref><ref name=Irish>{{cite news|last=Cassidy|first=Coleman|title=Definition of abortion is crucial gynaecologist |newspaper=The Irish Times|date=10 May 2000|page=6|quote=The definition of abortion is crucial to the efforts of the all-party Oireachtas committee, when it comes to make its recommendations, Dr Alistair McFar lane, a retired obstetrician and gynaecologist, told the hearing. No definition appeared in the Green Paper, he said, and the committee had heard a number of accounts from the various medical experts in the past week which differed as to whether or not the ending of pregnancy in certain procedures (carried out by all obstetricians on medical grounds) amounted to abortion.}}<!--|accessdate=3 January 2013--></ref> and Canada,<ref>{{cite news |last=Brunt|first=Stephen|title=MDs seek precise definition in new law|newspaper=The Globe and Mail (Canada)|date=28 July 1988}}<!--|accessdate=3 January 2013--></ref> have expressed concern over ambiguous definitions of abortion. Even in situations where there is a clear definition of abortion, it does not always match definitions of related terms in effect in the same [[jurisdiction]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schoen|first=Wendy L.|title=NOTE AND COMMENT: CONFLICT IN THE PARAMETERS DEFINING LIFE AND DEATH IN MISSOURI STATUTES|journal=[[American Journal of Law & Medicine]]|year=1990|volume=16|issue=555 |quote=The mere fact that a certain class of decisions is difficult cannot justify the absence of consistent supporting standards. Each state must compare the language of its statutes to determine whether the definitions of the parameters of life conflict. If these definitions conflict, as is the case with Missouri's Definition of Death and abortion regulation statutes, the state must amend the existing language to bring into concert the criteria defining these parameters. Each state should decide whether to accomplish this goal by changing its statute in which death is defined or by changing any other statute with conflicting criteria. |url=https://litigation-essentials.lexisnexis.com/webcd/app?action=DocumentDisplay&crawlid=1&doctype=cite&docid=16+Am.+J.+L.+and+Med.+555&srctype=smi&srcid=3B15&key=932f3a95bef438065ab1a7a0fecf85e3 |accessdate=24 November 2013}}</ref>
==Examples of definitions== The following is a partial list of definitions as stated by [[obstetrics and gynecology]] (OB/GYN) textbooks, dictionaries, and [[encyclopedias]]:
;Major OB/GYN textbooks * The [[National Center for Health Statistics]] defines an "abortus" as "[a] fetus or embryo removed or expelled from the uterus during the first half of gestation—20 weeks or less, or in the absence of accurate dating criteria, born weighing < 500 g." They also define "birth" as "[t]he complete expulsion or extraction from the mother of a fetus after 20 weeks' gestation. [...] in the absence of accurate dating criteria, fetuses weighing <500 g are usually not considered births, but rather are termed abortuses for purposes of vital statistics."<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Cunningham|editor1-first=FG|editor2-last=Leveno|editor2-first=KJ|editor3-last=Bloom|editor3-first=SL|editor4-last=Hauth|editor4-first=JC|editor5-last=Rouse|editor5-first=DJ|editor6-last=Spong|editor6-first=CY|chapter=1. Overview of Obstetrics|title=Williams Obstetrics|edition=23|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill Medical]]|year=2010|isbn=978-0-07-149701-5}}</ref> * "[T]he standard medical definition of abortion [is] termination of a pregnancy when the fetus is not viable".<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Gabbe|editor1-first=Steven G.|editor1-link=Steven Gabbe|editor2-last=Niebyl|editor2-first=Jennifer R.|editor3-last=Simpson|editor3-first=Joe Leigh|year=2007|title=Obstetrics: Normal and Problem Pregnancies|edition=5|publisher=[[Churchill Livingstone]]|chapter=51. Legal and Ethical Issues in Obstetric Practice|isbn=978-0-443-06930-7|last1=Annas|first1=George J.|authorlink1=George Annas|last2=Elias|first2=Sherman}}</ref> * "Termination of a pregnancy, whether spontaneous or induced."<ref>{{cite book|first1=Melissa J.|last1=Kottke|first2=Mimi|last2=Zieman|chapter=33. Management of Abortion|editor1-first=John A.|editor1-last=Rock|editor2-first=Howard W.|editor2-last=Jones III|year=2008|edition=10|publisher=[[Lippincott Williams & Wilkins]]|isbn=978-0-7817-7234-1|title=TeLinde's Operative Gynecology}}</ref>
;Other OB/GYN textbooks * "Termination of pregnancy before 20 weeks' gestation calculated from date of onset of last [[menses]]. An alternative definition is delivery of a fetus with a weight of less than 500 g. If abortion occurs before 12 weeks' gestation, it is called early; from 12 to 20 weeks it is called late."<ref>{{cite book|last=Katz|first=Vern L.|publisher=[[Mosby (publisher)|Mosby]]|year=2007|edition=5|title=Katz: Comprehensive Gynecology|editor1-last=Katz|editor1-first=Vern L.|editor2-last=Lentz|editor2-first=Gretchen M.|editor3-last=Lobo|editor3-first=Rogerio A.|editor4-last=Gershenson|editor4-first=David M.|chapter=16. Spontaneous and Recurrent Abortion - Etiology, Diagnosis, Treatment|isbn=9780323029513 }}</ref> * "Abortion is the spontaneous or induced termination of pregnancy before fetal viability. Because popular use of the word abortion implies a deliberate pregnancy termination, some prefer the word miscarriage to refer to spontaneous fetal loss before viability [...] The National Center for Health Statistics, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the World Health Organization (WHO) define abortion as pregnancy termination prior to 20 weeks' gestation or a fetus born weighing less than 500 g. Despite this, definitions vary widely according to state laws."<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Schorge|editor1-first=John O.|editor2-first=Joseph I.|editor2-last=Schaffer|editor3-first=Lisa M.|editor3-last=Halvorson|editor4-first=Barbara L.|editor4-last=Hoffman|editor5-first=Karen D.|editor5-last=Bradshaw|editor6-first=F. Gary|editor6-last=Cunningham|year=2008|title=Williams Gynecology|edition=1|publisher=McGraw-Hill Medical|isbn=978-0-07-147257-9|chapter=6. First-Trimester Abortion}}</ref>
;Major [[medical dictionaries]] * "The spontaneous or induced termination of pregnancy before the fetus reaches a viable age."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tabers.com/tabersonline/ub/view/Tabers/143003/37/abortion |title=Taber's Medical Dictionary: abortion |publisher=[[F. A. Davis Company|F.A. Davis]] |work=[[Taber's Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary]] |accessdate=14 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zRoq1nVk?url=http://www.tabers.com/tabersonline/ub/view/Tabers/143003/37/abortion? |archivedate=15 June 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> * "Expulsion from the uterus an embryo or fetus prior to the stage of viability (20 weeks' gestation or fetal weight <500g). A distinction made between [abortion] and premature birth: premature infants are those born after the stage of viability but prior to 37 weeks."<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Stedman's Medical Dictionary]]|publisher=[[Lippincott Williams & Wilkins]]|edition=27|isbn=0683400088}}</ref> * "[P]remature expulsion from the uterus of the products of conception, either the embryo or a nonviable fetus."<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Dorland's Illustrated Medical Dictionary]]|publisher=[[Saunders (publisher)|Saunders]]|year=2007|isbn=9781416023647|edition=31}}</ref>
;Other medical dictionaries * "[T]he termination of a pregnancy after, accompanied by, resulting in, or closely followed by the death of the embryo or fetus".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/medlineplus/abortion |title=Medical Dictionary |publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]] |location=Springfield, Mass. |work=[[Merriam-Webster's Medical Dictionary]] |accessdate=15 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zTA1aALZ?url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/medlineplus/abortion |archivedate=15 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> * "Induced termination of pregnancy, involving destruction of the embryo or fetus." "abortion."<ref>{{cite book|title=The American Heritage Science Dictionary |location=Boston |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |year=2005 |isbn=9780618455041}}</ref> * "Interruption of pregnancy before the fetus has attained a stage of viability, usually before the 24th gestational week." "abortion."<ref>{{cite book|title=Cambridge Dictionary of Human Biology and Evolution |location=Cambridge; New York|publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2005 |oclc=54374716}}</ref> * "[A] spontaneous or deliberate ending of pregnancy before the fetus can be expected to survive." "abortion."<ref>{{cite book|title=Mosby's Emergency Dictionary |location=Philadelphia |publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences |year=1998|oclc=37553784}}{{Verify source|date=October 2011}}</ref> * "[A] situation where a fetus leaves the uterus before it is fully developed, especially during the first 28 weeks of pregnancy, or a procedure which causes this to happen...[T]o have an abortion to have an operation to make a fetus leave the uterus during the first period of pregnancy."<ref>{{cite book |contribution="abortion" |title=Dictionary of Medical Terms |location=London |publisher=A & C Black |year=2005 |oclc=55634250}}</ref> * "1. Induced termination of a pregnancy with destruction of the fetus or embryo; therapeutic abortion. 2. Spontaneous abortion."<ref>{{cite book |title=The American Heritage Medical Dictionary |isbn=0618947256|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2008 |edition=reprint |page=2 |oclc=608212441}}</ref> * "Although the term abortion is generic and implies a premature termination of pregnancy for any reason, the lay public better understands the word ‘miscarriage’ for involuntary fetal loss or fetal wastage."<ref>{{cite book |title=The Dictionary of Modern Medicine |page=3 |year=1992 |publisher=Parthenon Publishing |isbn=1850703213}}</ref> * "The termination of pregnancy or premature expulsion of the products of conception by any means, usually before fetal viability."<ref>{{cite book |title=Churchill’s Medical Dictionary|page=3|year=1989|isbn=0443086915|publisher=Churchill Livingstone}}</ref>
;Bibliographies * "An abortion refers to the termination of a pregnancy. It can be ''induced'' (see Definitions, Terminology, and Reference Resources) through a pharmacological or a surgical procedure, or it may be spontaneous (also called miscarriage)." "Definitions of abortion vary across and within countries as well as among different institutions. Language used to refer to abortion often also reflects societal and political opinions and not only scientific knowledge (Grimes and Gretchen 2010). Popular use of the word abortion implies a deliberate pregnancy termination, whereas a miscarriage is used to refer to spontaneous fetal loss when the fetus is not viable (i.e., not yet unable to survive independently outside the womb)."<ref name="oxfordbiblio"/>
;[[English dictionary#Major English dictionaries|Major English dictionaries]] (general-purpose) * "1. a. The expulsion or removal from the womb of a developing embryo or fetus, spec. (Med.) in the period before it is capable of independent survival, occurring as a result either of natural causes (more fully spontaneous abortion) or of a deliberate act (more fully induced abortion); the early or premature termination of pregnancy with loss of the fetus; an instance of this."<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |chapter= abortion, n.|chapterurl=http://www.oed.com/viewdictionaryentry/Entry/503 |edition=Third |quote=September 2009; online version September 2011 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}}</ref> * "[A]n operation or other procedure to terminate pregnancy before the fetus is viable" or "[T]he premature termination of pregnancy by spontaneous or induced expulsion of a nonviable fetus from the uterus".<ref>{{cite web|title=abortion|publisher=[[HarperCollins Publishers]]|work=Collins English Dictionary - Complete & Unabridged 11th Edition|accessdate=7 October 2012|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/abortion}}</ref> * "[T]he removal of an embryo or fetus from the uterus in order to end a pregnancy" or "[A]ny of various surgical methods for terminating a pregnancy, especially during the first six months."<ref>{{cite web|title=abortion|work=[[Dictionary.com]]Unabridged|publisher=[[Random House, Inc.]]|date=27 June 2011|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/abortion}}</ref> * "[T]he termination of a pregnancy after, accompanied by, resulting in, or closely followed by the death of the embryo or fetus: as (a) spontaneous expulsion of a human fetus during the first 12 weeks of gestation (b) induced expulsion of a human fetus (c) expulsion of a fetus by a domestic animal often due to infection at any time before completion of pregnancy."<ref>''[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/abortion Merriam-Webster Dictionary]'', from [[Merriam-Webster]], an Encyclopædia Britannica Company.</ref> * "1. ''medicine'' the removal of an embryo or fetus from the uterus before it is sufficiently developed to survive independently, deliberately induced by the use of drugs or by surgical procedures. Also called termination or induced abortion. 2. ''medicine'' the spontaneous expulsion of an embryo or fetus from the uterus before it is sufficiently developed to survive independently. Also called miscarriage, spontaneous abortion."<ref>''Chambers 21st Century Dictionary''. London: Chambers Harrap, 2001.</ref> * "a medical operation to end a pregnancy so that the baby is not born alive".<ref>''[[Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English]]'', [http://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/abortion online edition].</ref>
;Other dictionaries * "The deliberate termination of a pregnancy, usually before the embryo or fetus is capable of independent life."<ref>{{cite book |title=The American Heritage New Dictionary of Cultural Literacy |edition=3rd |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Company]] |year=2005 |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/abortion}}</ref> * "A term that, in philosophy, theology, and social debates, often means the deliberate termination of pregnancy before the fetus is able to survive outside the uterus. However, participants in these debates sometimes use the term abortion simply to mean the termination of pregnancy before birth, regardless of whether the fetus is viable or not."<ref>"abortion."''Dictionary of World Philosophy''. London: Routledge, 2001.</ref> * "1. An artificially induced termination of a pregnancy for the purpose of destroying an embryo or fetus. 2. The spontaneous expulsion of an embryo or fetus before viability;"<ref>{{cite book| last=Garner| first=Bryan A.|authorlink=Bryan A. Garner| title=[[Black's Law Dictionary]]| edition=9th|date=June 2009| publisher=Thomson West| isbn=9780314199492}}</ref>
;Encyclopedias * "[T]he expulsion of a fetus from the uterus before it has reached the stage of viability (in human beings, usually about the 20th week of gestation)."<ref>{{cite web |title=Abortion (pregnancy) |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |work=Encyclopædia Britannica Online |year=2011 |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/1498/abortion |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zjwaLKR7?url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/1498/abortion |archivedate=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> * "Expulsion of the products of conception before the embryo or fetus is viable. Any interruption of human pregnancy prior to the 28th week is known as abortion."<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=The Columbia Encyclopedia|location=New York|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=2008|title=Abortion}} * "The expulsion or removal of a fetus from the womb before it is capable of independent survival." {{cite encyclopedia |title=Abortion |encyclopedia=World Encyclopedia, Oxford Reference Online |publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008}}</ref> * "[Abortion] is commonly misunderstood outside medical circles. In general terms, the word 'abortion' simply means the failure of something to reach fulfilment or maturity. Medically, abortion means loss of the fetus, for any reason, before it is able to survive outside the womb. The term covers accidental or spontaneous ending, or miscarriage, of pregnancy as well as deliberate termination. The terms 'spontaneous abortion' and 'miscarriage' are synonymous and are defined as loss of the fetus before the twenty-eighth week of pregnancy. This definition implies a legal perception of the age at which a fetus can survive out of the womb. With great advances in recent years in the ability to keep very premature babies alive, this definition is in need of revision."<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Abortion and miscarriage|encyclopedia=The Royal Society of Medicine Health Encyclopedia|location=London|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|year=2000}}</ref> * "Abortion is the intentional removal of a fetus or an embryo from a mother's womb for purposes other than that of either producing a live birth or disposing of a dead embryo."<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Abortion|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Human Rights Issues since 1945|location=[[Santa Barbara, California]]|year=1999|publisher=Routledge|edition=1|isbn=978-1579581664}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Robotics companies]] to [[Category:Robotics companies of the United States]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = DragonLord Enterprises, Inc. |logo = |type = [[Private company|Private]] |genre = |foundation = 1996 |founder = |location_city = [[North Hills, Los Angeles|North Hills, California]] |location_country = United States |location = |locations = |area_served = |key_people = |industry = [[Mobile Development]]
[[Artificial Intelligence]]
[[Robotics]] |products = [[Tetris| Tetris on Kyocera phones]] |services = [[Artificial Intelligence| Artificial Intelligence solutions]] |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |assets = |equity = |owner = |num_employees = |parent = |divisions = |subsid = |slogan = |homepage = [http://www.dragonlord.com/ DragonLord.com] |footnotes = |intl = }} '''DragonLord Enterprises, Inc.''' is an American corporation that develops games, mobile apps, and 3D simulations. Under the name Sequoia Consulting, it also specializes in robotics, machine learning, and applied artificial intelligence. DragonLord created the first adventure game running on a cell phone in the world. == Mobile Games == DragonLord created the first adventure game for cell phones in the world, ''Cavern Crawl'', in 2001. DragonLord was the first developer in America to create games for cell phones, and one of the first in the world, after Nokia's ''Snake''.{{cite web|title=User's Guide for the Kyocera 2235 phone (English version)|url=http://www.kyocerawireless.com/2200-phone/pdf/2235_user_guide_english.pdf|publisher=Kyocera Wireless|accessdate=3 November 2011}} DragonLord's ''Cavern Crawl'' and ''Mystic I Ching'' were factory-built into the firmware of such cell phones as the Kyocera Model 2235 handset, distributed by Verizon;{{cite web|title=Kyocera 2235 Cell Phone|url=http://www.epinions.com/review/Kyocera_2235_Cellular_Phone/content_76337811076|publisher=Epinions|accessdate=3 November 2011}} the S14 Opal, distributed by Cricket and MetroPCS;{{cite web|title=Kyocera Opal S14 User Guide|url=http://www.kyocera-wireless.com/opal-phone/pdf/opal_user_guide_english.pdf|publisher=Kyocera|accessdate=3 November 2011}} and the 2255{{cite web|title=User's Guide for the Kyocera 2255 Phone|url=http://www.kyocera-wireless.com/2200-phone/pdf/2255_user_guide_english.pdf|publisher=Kyocera Wireless|accessdate=3 November 2011}} and 2325,{{cite web|title=User's Guide for the Kyocera 2325 Phone|url=http://www.kyocera-wireless.com/2300-phone/pdf/2325_user_guide_english.pdf|publisher=Kyocera Wireless|accessdate=3 November 2011}} distributed by Sprint PCS in America{{cite news|title=Sprint Introduces Feature-Rich Kyocera 2255|url=http://www.mobiletechnews.com/info/2001/11/01/003202.html|accessdate=3 November 2011|newspaper=Mobile Tech News|date=November 1, 2001}} and Virgin Mobile in the UK.{{cite web|title=Kyocera 2255|url=http://www.phonescoop.com/phones/phone.php?p=7|publisher=Phone Scoop|accessdate=3 November 2011}} The games were noted for providing animation and game play that were ahead of their time.{{cite news|last=Charny|first=Ben|title=Sprint looks to liven up wireless games|url=http://news.cnet.com/Sprint-looks-to-liven-up-wireless-games/2100-1033_3-918180.html|accessdate=3 November 2011|newspaper=CNet|date=May 20, 2002}} DragonLord also made multiple versions of ''Tetris'', that were built into the factory firmware of various Kyocera handsets through at least 2004.{{cite web|title=Slider User Guide|url=http://www.kyocera-wireless.com/slider-phone/pdf/se44_user_guide_largeprint_english.pdf|publisher=Kyocera Wireless|accessdate=3 November 2011}}{{cite web|title=Kyocera 3245 User Guide|url=http://www.kyocera-wireless.com/3200-phone/pdf/3245_user_guide_english.pdf|publisher=Kyocera Wireless|accessdate=3 November 2011}} ==Robotics and A.I.== DragonLord's Sequoia Consulting created the software for a humanoid robot for NASA JPL in 2006.{{cite book|title=System Integration of a Humanoid Robot Testbed, Final Report|year=2006|publisher=DragonLord Enterprises, Inc|location=Sherman Oaks, CA}} The robot was one of the first humanoid robots to integrate speech recognition of commands and speech generation of responses. It used a real-time expert system shell to plan and sequence actions. It used primitive model-based stereo vision to locate and track objects in its environment. It was able to turn, walk over to a spar, squat down, bend over, and pick the spar up, using an arm with no wrist joints.{{cite web|title=JPL (NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratories): System Integration of a Humanoid Robot|url=http://www.seqcon.com/caseJPL.html|publisher=Sequoia Consulting|accessdate=3 November 2011}} ==Popular culture== DragonLord is featured in the book ''The Fat Man on Game Audio''.{{cite book|last=Sanger|first=George Alistair|title=The Fat Man on Game Audio: Tasty Morsels of Sonic Goodness|year=2003|publisher=New Riders Publishing|location=America|isbn=1-59273-009-4|pages=86–91,118–119}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.dragonlord.com/ Official website] [[Category:Mobile game companies]] [[Category:Robotics companies of the United States]] [[Category:Information technology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence]] [[Category:Video game companies of the United States]]

revision.text:
{{for|the fictional suicide machine|Suicide booth}} {{Suicide sidebar}} {{Euthanasia}} A '''euthanasia device''' is a machine engineered to allow an individual to die quickly with minimal pain. The most common devices are those designed to help [[terminally ill]] people die by [[voluntary euthanasia]] or [[assisted suicide]] without prolonged [[pain]]. They may be operated by a second party, such as a [[physician]], or by the person wishing to die. There is an ongoing debate on the [[ethics]] of euthanasia and the use of euthanasia devices.
==Notable devices==
===Thanatron=== Invented by [[Jack Kevorkian]], to use this device and called it a "Thanatron" or death machine after the Greek [[daemon (classical mythology)|daemon]], [[Thanatos]]. It worked by pushing a button to deliver the euthanizing drugs mechanically through an [[Intravenous therapy|IV]]. It had three canisters mounted on a metal frame. Each bottle had a [[syringe]] that connected to a single IV line in the person's arm. One contained [[saline (medicine)|saline]], another contained a sleep-inducing [[barbiturate]] called [[sodium thiopental]] and the third a lethal mixture of [[potassium chloride]], which immediately stopped the heart, and [[pancuronium bromide]], a paralytic medication to prevent spasms during the dying process.<ref name="lopes1">{{cite book|title=Dying with Dignity: A Legal Approach to Assisted Death: A Legal Approach to Assisted Death|last=Lopes|date=2015-04-28|publisher=Praeger|isbn=978-1440830976|location=Santa Barbara, California; Denver, Colorado|page=5|first1=Giza}}<!--|accessdate=2016-04-18 --></ref> Two deaths were assisted with this method.
===Mercitron=== Kevorkian assisted others with a device that employed a [[gas mask]] fed by a canister of [[carbon monoxide]] which was called "Mercitron" (mercy machine).<ref name="lopes1" /> This became necessary because Kevorkian's medical license had been revoked after the first two deaths, and he could no longer have legal access to the substances required for the "Thanatron". It was a rudimentary device consisting of a canister of carbon monoxide attached to a face mask with a tube. A valve must be released to start the gas flowing. Depending on the person's disability, a makeshift handle may be attached to the valve to make it easier to turn. Or, with the valve in the "open" position, a clip or clothespin could be clamped on the tubing. Pulling it off allows the gas to flow. By Kevorkian's estimates, this method took 10 minutes or longer. Sometimes he encouraged people to take sedatives or muscle relaxants to keep them calm as they breathed deeply of the gas.
===Deliverance Machine=== [[File:Euthanasia machine (Australia).JPG|thumb|340px|Philip Nitschke's "Deliverance Machine"]]
The Deliverance Machine was invented by [[Philip Nitschke]]. It consisted of software entitled Deliverance, that came on a special laptop that could be connected to an IV in a person's arm. The computer program asked a series of questions to confirm the person's intent to die. After answering affirmatively to all of the questions, a [[lethal injection]] of [[barbiturate]]s was triggered.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB835824113352032000?mod=googlewsj|title=Death by Computer|publisher=online.wsj.com|accessdate=2009-01-06}}</ref>
In an interview Nitschke said that, even if it had been legal for a doctor to give a lethal injection, he preferred that the patient be in control of the administration of the drugs. Reducing the role of a physician also allowed a patient to be alone with their family during the euthanasia process.<ref name=lopez>{{cite|author=Kathryn Jean Lopez|title=Euthanasia Sets Sail An interview with Philip Nitschke, the other “Dr. Death.”|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/420133/euthanasia-sets-sail-kathryn-jean-lopez|date=5 June 2001}}</ref>
The machine was used, legally, while the Australian [[Northern Territory]]'s [[Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995]] was in effect; the act was eventually nullified by legislation of the Australian Parliament.<ref name=lopez/>
===Exit International's euthanasia device=== The [[EXIT (Australia)|Exit International]] euthanasia device was invented by [[Philip Nitschke]] in 2008. It uses a canister of [[nitrogen]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,24813754-2682,00.html|title=New death device to be launched in Adelaide|publisher=www.news.com.au|accessdate=2008-12-19|last=Wheatley|first=Kim|date=2008-12-16}}</ref> a [[suicide bag|plastic suicide bag]], and a plastic tube with one end attached to the gas canister and the other fixed inside the bag by a tie held by adhesive tape.<ref name="pph">{{cite book |last=Nitschke |first1=Philip |authorlink=Philip Nitschke |last2=Stewart |first2=Fiona |authorlink2=Fiona Stewart (author) |url=https://www.peacefulpillhandbook.com/ |title=The Peaceful Pill Handbook |publisher=Exit International US Ltd |date=2010 |isbn=978-0978878825 |accessdate=2016-04-15 }}</ref> Nitschke said, "That idea of giving people access to a means of feeling that they're back in control of this issue is actually a way of prolonging life. It may seem paradoxical, but what we find is when people feel that they're back in control, they're less likely to do desperate things."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/12/18/2449786.htm|title=Nitschke's suicide machine slammed |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], www.abc.net.au|accessdate=2008-12-19|date=2008-12-17 }}</ref>
;Background The basic principle of autoeuthanasia by anoxia was first described in the book ''[[Final Exit]]'' by [[Derek Humphry]] in 1991.<ref name=Humphry1991>{{Cite book|last=Humphry|first=Derek|year=1991|title=Final Exit: the Practicalities of Self-Deliverance and Assisted Suicide for the Dying|isbn=978-0-385-33653-6|publisher=Delta Trade Paperback|location=New York}}</ref> The original methodology was devised, using helium, by the ''NuTech'' group.<ref>{{cite news |last=Martindale |first=Diane |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/a-culture-of-death/ |title=A Culture of Death |work=[[Scientific American]] |publisher=[[Scientific American]] |date=2005-06-01 |accessdate=2016-04-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.finalexit.org/ergo_nutech_new_technology.html |title=NuTech Report |work=ERGO |accessdate=2016-04-18 }}</ref>
;Description Nitschke described his device as a modification of the exit bag with helium method described in ''[[The Peaceful Pill Handbook]]''. Helium was replaced by a cylinder of compressed nitrogen and a regulator to supply the nitrogen into a plastic bag. One advantage of this method was the availability of larger amounts of nitrogen and flow rates last longer. Nitschke states that nitrogen is also more physiologically inert than helium, with less chance of adverse reaction,<ref name="pph" /> and that loss of consciousness is quick with death following within minutes.<ref name="pph" /> Unlike helium cylinders, nitrogen cylinders can be refilled in the event of leakage and nitrogen gas can't be detected during an autopsy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-01-14/test-detects-suicides-from-natural-deaths/1208578 |title=Test detects suicides from natural deaths |work=ABC News |publisher=www.abc.net.au |date=14 January 2010 |accessdate=2010-01-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/euthanasia-group-to-show-west-aussies-how-to-die-well-20130503-2ixgd.html |title=Euthanasia group to show West Aussies how to die 'well' |author=Orr, Aleisha |date=3 May 2013 |work=WAToday|accessdate=8 May 2013}}</ref>
;Process The principle behind the device is [[oxygen]] deprivation that leads to [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], [[asphyxia]] and death within minutes. Deprivation of oxygen in the presence of [[carbon dioxide]] creates panic and a sense of [[suffocation]] (the [[hypercapnia|hypercapnic]] alarm response), and struggling even when unconscious, whereas [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]] in the presence of an [[inert gas]], like [[nitrogen]], [[helium]] or [[argon]], does not.<ref name="pph" />
Close contact with an enclosed inert gas is lethal, but released into the open air, it quickly disperses, and is safe for others. It is neither flammable nor explosive. Humphry's book describes close contact with the gas achieved by enclosing the head in a strong, clear plastic bag, secured around the neck, with the inert gas fed into the bag by plastic tubing.<ref name="Humphry1991" />
Suicides using this method are documented in the forensic literature.<ref name="pmid21394956">{{cite journal |vauthors=Howard MO, Hall MT, Edwards JD, Vaughn MG, Perron BE, Winecker RE |title=Suicide by asphyxiation due to helium inhalation |journal=[[The American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology]] |volume=32 |issue=1 |pages=61–70 |year=2011 |pmid=21394956 |doi= 10.1097/paf.0b013e3181ed7a2d|url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/78181/1/heliumsuicide.pdf}}</ref> In the study ''Asphyxial suicide with helium and a plastic bag'' (Ogden et al.), the authors describe a typical case history, in which an elderly cancer sufferer used a plastic bag which was secured over her head, a [[helium]] tank, and a plastic hose attached to the tank valve and plastic bag.<ref name="pmid12198347">{{cite journal |last1=Ogden |first1=Russel D. |last2=Wooten |first2=Rae H. |title=Asphyxial Suicide with Helium and a Plastic Bag |journal=American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology |volume=23 |issue=3 |pages=234–7 |date=September 2002 |pmid=12198347 |doi=10.1097/01.PAF.0000022963.33157.9B |url=http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0195-7910&volume=23&issue=3&spage=234|doi-broken-date=2018-10-03 }}</ref> The authors noted that a suicide bag filled with helium will cause almost immediate unconsciousness, followed within minutes by death.<ref name="pmid12198347" /> Time to loss of consciousness in a bag filled with nitrogen is 15 seconds, according to professors Copeland, Pappas and Parr, who campaigned for a more humane execution method in the US state of Oklahoma.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shuler |first=Jack |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/03/can-executions-be-more-humane/388249/ |title=Can Executions Be More Humane? |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=2015-03-20 |accessdate=2016-04-18 }}</ref>
===Sarco machine=== In 2017 Nitschke invented the 3D-printed suicide capsule, which he named "the Sarco machine".<ref name="capsule">{{cite news |last=Overington |first=Caroline |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/health-science/philip-nitschke-invents-suicide-capsule-with-3d-printer/news-story/318561693f3a6eee1e10069df83a3839?nk=8a500b8067a5ef429d365255e635c3d2-1511568834 |title=Philip Nitschke invents suicide capsule with 3D printer |work=[[The Australian]] |publisher=[[News Corporation]] |date=2017-11-25 |accessdate=2017-11-25 }}</ref> The Sarco capsule would contain a touchpad and nitrogen, and once an activation code is entered, "the person is again asked if they wish to die".<ref name="capsule" /> An affirmative answer causes nitrogen to flow into the capsule, displacing oxygen, and death follows shortly thereafter. The Sarco machine cannot be printed on small 3D printers. The Sarco offers a "euphoric death".<ref name="hp2018" />
Nitschke plans to release the [[open-source model|open source]] plans for the Sarco by 2019.<ref name="hp2018">{{cite news |last=Nitschke |first=Philip |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/sarco-death-philip-nitschke_us_5abbb574e4b03e2a5c7853ca |title=Here’s Why I Invented A ‘Death Machine’ That Lets People Take Their Own Lives |work=[[Huffington Post]] |date=2018-04-05 |accessdate=2018-04-06 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Euthanasia]] *[[Suicide bag]] *[[Suicide booth]]
== References ==
{{reflist|30em}}
