{{Infobox film | name = Love | image = Angels & Airwaves - Love film poster.jpg | border = yes | alt = Love 2011 poster | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[William Eubank]] | producer = {{unbulleted list|[[Angels & Airwaves]]|Mark Eaton|Daniel Figur|Vertel Scott|Nate Kolbeck}} | writer = William Eubank | starring = [[Gunner Wright]] | music = Angels & Airwaves | cinematography = William Eubank | editing = {{unbulleted list|Brian Berdan|Scott Chestnut}} | studio = {{unbulleted list|New Dog Media|Griffin Interplanetary Studios ([[Visual effects|vfx]])|Five VFX ([[Visual effects|vfx]])|[[Zoic Studios]] ([[Visual effects|vfx]])|[[Company 3]] ([[Color grading|post]])}} | distributor = [[National CineMedia]] {{small|(United States)}} | released = {{Film date|2011|2|2|[[Santa Barbara International Film Festival|SBIFF]]|2011|8|10|United States|2011|11|1|International}} | runtime = 86 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $500,000 | gross = $1,495,102 }} '''''Love''''' is a 2011 [[science fiction film|science fiction]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] produced and scored by the [[alternative rock]] band [[Angels & Airwaves]]. The film is the [[directorial debut]] of filmmaker [[William Eubank]]. The film's [[Premiere|world premiere]] took place on February 2, 2011 at the 26th Annual [[Santa Barbara International Film Festival]] and the film was later featured in the [[Seattle International Film Festival]], [[Fantasia Festival|FanTasia 2011]], and a number of other festivals around the world. The film was screened in 460 theatres across the United States on August 10, 2011, in the [[Angels & Airwaves Presents Love Live|Love Live]] event.{{cite web |url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2011/07/15/angels-and-airwaves-love-live-event/ |title=MTV News | EXCLUSIVE: Angels & Airwaves Present 3-For-1 Live Music And Film Experience |publisher=moviesblog.mtv.com |date=July 15, 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-19}} ''Love'' portrays the personal-[[Psychological trauma|psychological]] [[Social isolation|effects of isolation]] and [[loneliness]] when an [[astronaut]] becomes stranded in space and through this, emphasizes the importance of [[Human interaction|human connection]] and [[love]]. Additionally, it touches on the [[Risks to civilization, humans and planet Earth|fragility of humanity's existence]] (explored through a [[Dying Earth (subgenre)|dying Earth]]-[[Apocalyptic and post-apocalyptic fiction|apocalyptic]] [[Doomsday event|doomsday]] scenario) inspired by the cautions of [[Carl Sagan]] in ''[[Pale Blue Dot (book)|Pale Blue Dot]]'' and considers the importance of [[memory|memories]] and [[narrative|stories]] as humanity's legacy.{{cite interview |last=Eubank |first=William |subjectlink=William Eubank |interviewer=SBIFF |title=Director Q&A |location=Santa Barbara, California |date=2011-02-03 |work=Santa Barbara International Film Festival}} ==Plot== During an 1864 battle of the [[American Civil War]], a lone [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] soldier, Captain Lee Briggs (Bradley Horne), is dispatched on a mission to investigate a mysterious object reported to Union forces. He leaves to venture on the mission. 175 years later, in the year 2039, United States Astronaut Lee Miller ([[Gunner Wright]]) is sent to the [[International Space Station]] (ISS) as a one-man [[skeleton crew]] to examine if it is safe for use and to perform necessary modifications after it had been abandoned two decades earlier for reasons unknown. Shortly after arriving on board, tumultuous events break out on Earth, eventually resulting in Miller losing contact with [[Flight controller#Capsule Communicator|CAPCOM]] and finding himself stranded in orbit alone, forced to helplessly watch events on Earth from portholes 200 miles above his home planet. Miller struggles to maintain his sanity while in isolation by interacting with [[Instant film|Polaroid]] pictures of former ISS crew members left aboard the ship. When the station has some power glitches, Miller journeys into an [[International Space Station#Unpressurised elements|unpressurised module of the space station]] to perform repairs and discovers the 1864 journal of Briggs. Miller reads Briggs's account of the war and becomes enthralled by the mysterious object he is searching for, not realizing he will soon become more familiar with the very same object, and not by accident. In 2045, six years after losing contact with CAPCOM and with a failing [[oxygen]] system inside the ISS, Miller puts on a [[space suit]] and goes for a [[Extravehicular activity|spacewalk]], deciding that it would be easier for him to detach his [[tether]] and slowly drift towards Earth and to burn in the atmosphere than slowly suffocate to death on board the ISS. He finds, however, that he is unable to go through with his suicide. Miller is seen still aboard the ISS, presumably much later: his hair has grown extremely long, and he is extensively tattooed. He has drawn sketches of people and battles of the Civil War from the journal all over the interior of the ISS. The cramped quarters of the space station have become a rat's nest symbolic of his diminished sanity. He then seems to be contacted from outside the ISS, and to receive instructions to dock and transfer over. He does so, and seems to arrive in a giant uninhabited structure of distinctly human making. It is unclear whether this is reality or imagined by Miller, who is now insane. Miller wanders around until he happens upon a server [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] where he finds a book titled "'A Love Story' As Told by 'You'". Inside this book, he finds pictures of Captain Lee Briggs with his discovery, a gigantic cube-like alien object that may have helped advance Human society. In the index of the book, Miller finds a reference to himself and types it into the computer prompt. He then finds himself inside a generic hotel room, where a disembodied voice says: {{quotation|How are you doing, Lee? Sorry about this projection, but it's the only way we could reach you. We can't tell you how relieved we are to have you here. Now, before we get ahead of ourselves, we have to tell you something. You're the last one, it's all gone. We understand how you might feel. Connection is perhaps the most cherished thing any being can have. That's the thing. That's why we've been listening. The place you see here is a scrapbook of sorts, a collection of memories and mementos of mankind's brief existence. It's a good thing we found you. We look forward to meeting you, Lee.}} During the speech, we see the same cube-like object in space in the year 2045. The viewer is left to assume that this object has 'obtained' Lee Miller and is speaking directly to him. The film ends with the voice of a computer speaking of human connections and love. ==Production== File:Eubank-Love-2011-Figur-ISS-Set-Ext-1.jpg|''The ISS set built in a driveway, seen here protected from the rain by plastic tarps.'' File:Eubank-Love-2011-Figur-ISS-3.jpg|''The interior of the space station set.'' File:Eubank-Love-2011-Figur-Gunner-Wright-modified.jpg|[[Gunner Wright]] in the film ''Love''. Reviewers have also noted the production design, with the space-station set reportedly being built in William Eubank's parents' backyard. In a [[making-of]] video uploaded to his [[Vimeo]] account, Eubank details the construction of the set and lists materials such as packing quilts, [[Medium-density fibreboard|MDF]], [[thermal bag|pizza bags]], [[velcro]], [[Building insulation|insulation]], [[Christmas lights]], and other salvaged material as components to the ISS set.{{cite video |url=http://vimeo.com/18634751 |title=Behind the Scenes}} According to Tom DeLonge, the production was going to rent the space station from another movie but instead opted to construct it from salvaged materials for budget reasons.{{cite web |url=http://www.rocksound.tv/features/article/tom-delonge-q-a |title=RockSound.tv | Tom Delonge Q + A |publisher=RockSound.tv |date=January 24, 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-04}} Early teasers were released in 2007 and 2009. On January 10, 2011, the film's final trailer was released on Apple Trailers. The release of this trailer saw coverage on several industry websites.[https://www.wired.com/underwire/2011/01/love-trailer/ Wired], [http://io9.com/5735263/did-the-lead-singer-from-blink-182-just-make-the-next-scifi-indie-smash io9], [http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/news/love-trailer-angels-and-airwaves.php Film School Rejects] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110118070703/http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/news/love-trailer-angels-and-airwaves.php |date=2011-01-18 }}, [http://www.firstshowing.net/2011/must-watch-stunning-sci-fi-trailer-for-angels-airwaves-love/ FirstShowing], [http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Listen-To-Angels-And-Airwaves-Oh-And-Watch-This-New-Trailer-For-Love-22668.html CinemaBlend], [http://www.slashfilm.com/angels-airwaves-love-trailer/ /Film], [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/blogs/heat-vision/video-angels-airwaves-love-trailer-72092 The Hollywood Reporter] Based on the style choices seen in the film's trailer, reviewers have mentioned similarities to ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'', ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'', and ''[[Solaris (2002 film)|Solaris]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.slashfilm.com/angels-airwaves-love-trailer/ |title=‘Love’ Trailer Channels ‘2001’, ‘Moon’ and ‘Solaris’ Into a Promising New Concoction | author=Russ Fischer |publisher=Slashfilm.com |date=January 17, 2011 |accessdate=2011-01-17}} ==Release== ===Festival circuit=== {{Quote box |quote=I can tell you, honestly, the movie is ten times better than I thought it would be. But it's not meant to compete with ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon|Transformers]]''. This is an [[Art film|art-house film]] and no band has really done this in a very long time. So we're hoping that we catch some people off guard and we're also hoping that we do something that is very credible as far its artistic acumen goes.{{cite web |url=http://www.thepunksite.com/interviews.php?page=angelsandairwaves |title=Angels & Airwaves Interview – Tom DeLonge and David Kennedy |publisher=ThePunksite.com |date=April 11, 2010 |accessdate=2010-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426022222/http://www.thepunksite.com/interviews.php?page=angelsandairwaves |archivedate=April 26, 2010 |df= }} |source= — [[Tom DeLonge]], April 11, 2010|align=right|width=25em}} The film's [[Premiere|world premiere]] took place on February 2, 2011 at the 26th Annual [[Santa Barbara International Film Festival]], with additional screenings on February 3, 4 and 5 at the Metro 4 and [[Arlington Theater]]. The film was screened for free on February 11 at the Riviera Theatre in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] as one of eleven films chosen as "Best of the Fest". The 2011 [[Seattle International Film Festival]] featured ''Love'' in both their Sci-Fi and Beyond Pathway and their New American Cinema program. The film played on May 21 at the Pacific Place Theatre and May 22 at the SIFF Cinema. The film played a third time, June 11, at the Egyptian Theatre. ''Love'' was accepted into the 2011 [[Fantasia Festival|Fantasia International Film Festival]] held in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]]. Its FanTasia screening on July 18 in Hall Theatre, as part of the festival's Camera Lucida Section, marked the film's international premiere. The film also screened in [[Athens]], [[Lund]], [[London]], [[Nantes]], [[South Korea]], [[Spain]], [[Israel]], and elsewhere. {| class="wikitable" |- ! |Date ! |Festival ! |Location ! |Awards ! |Link |-align="center" | align="center"| Feb 2–5, Feb 11 | align="left"| ''[[Santa Barbara International Film Festival]]'' | [[Santa Barbara, California]] {{flag|USA}} | ''Top 11 "Best of the Fest" Selection'' | [https://web.archive.org/web/20120402034959/http://sbiff.org/pub/2011OPG.html sbiff.org] |-align="center" | align="center"| May 21–22, Jun 11 | align="left"| ''[[Seattle International Film Festival]]'' | [[Seattle, Washington]] {{flag|USA}} | | [https://web.archive.org/web/20110810053919/http://www.siff.net/festival/film/detail.aspx?id=44249&fid=206 siff.net] |-align="center" | align="center"| Jul 18, Jul 25 | align="left"| ''[[Fantasia Festival]]'' | [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] {{flag|Canada}} | {{Laureate|Special Mention}}
''"for the resourcefulness and unwavering determination by a director to realize his unique vision"'' | [http://www.festivalfantasia.com/2011/en/films/film_detail.php?id=604 FanTasia] |-align="center" | colspan="5" style="text-align: center;" | ''Aug 10 – [[Angels & Airwaves Presents Love Live|Love Live]] Nationwide Screening {{flagicon|USA}}'' |-align="center" | align="center"| Sep 16 | align="left"| ''[[List of film festivals in Europe|Athens International Film Festival]]'' | [[Athens]], [[Attica (region)|Attica]]
{{flag|Greece}} | {{Laureate|Best Director}} | [http://en.aiff.gr/article.asp?catid=24169&subid=2&pubid=15173086 aiff.gr] |-align="center" | align="center"| Sep 19 | align="left"| ''[[European Fantastic Film Festivals Federation|Lund International Fantastic Film Festival]]'' | [[Lund]], [[Scania|Skåne]]
{{flag|Sweden}} | | [http://www.fff.se/en/film/love/ fff.se] |-align="center" | align="center"| Sep 28 | align="left"| ''[[Fantastic Fest]]'' | [[Austin, Texas]]
{{flag|USA}} | | [http://fantasticfest.festivalgenius.com/2011/films/love_williameubank_fantasticfest2011 FantasticFest.com] |-align="center" | align="center"| Oct 9 | align="left"| ''[[Sci-Fi-London|London Int. Festival of Science Fiction Film]]'' | [[London Borough of Camden|London]], [[England]]
{{flag|UK}} | ''Closing Night Film'' | [http://www.sci-fi-london.com/festival/2011/oktoberfest/programme/feature/angels-and-airwaves-love Sci-Fi London] |-align="center" | align="center"| Oct 9, Oct 11 | align="left"| ''[[Sitges Film Festival]]'' | [[Sitges]], [[Catalonia]]
{{flag|Spain}} | | [http://sitgesfilmfestival.com/eng/film/?id=10002095 Sitges Festival] |-align="center" | align="center"| Oct 1, Oct 15 | align="left"| ''Gwacheon International SF Festival'' | [[Gwacheon]], [[Gyeonggi-do]]
{{flag|South Korea}} | | [http://gisf.org/bbs/board.php?bo_table=movie&wr_id=29&page=3 gisf.org] |-align="center" | align="center"| Oct 17, Oct 20 | align="left"| ''[[ICon festival|Icon TLV]]'' | [[Tel Aviv]], [[Central District (Israel)|Central]]
{{flag|Israel}} | | [https://web.archive.org/web/20111209034017/http://www.icon.org.il/2011/node/2081 icon.org.il] |-align="center" | align="center"| Oct 23 | align="left"| ''[[Toronto After Dark Film Festival|Toronto After Dark]]'' | [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]
{{flag|Canada}} | {{Laureate|Best Special Effects}}

{{flag|Poland}} | | [http://www.americanfilmfestival.pl/film.do?id=5689 AFF Poland] |} ===Limited release=== {{Main|Angels & Airwaves Presents Love Live}} ''Love'' was shown nationwide {{clarify|date=December 2012}} on August 10, 2011.http://www.fathomevents.com/concerts/event/angelsandairwaves.aspx{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===DVD=== Angels & Airwaves released a [[box set]] containing the film ''Love'', the soundtrack to the film, ''Love Part I'', and the band's fourth studio album ''Love Part II'' on November 8, 2011. ==Reception== At the Santa Barbara International Film Festival, the film was originally slotted three showings but two additional showings in the Arlington Theatre were added after some original showings sold-out. Dennis Harvey, for [[Los Angeles]]-based magazine ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', wrote "[The film's] spiritual abstruseness and the script's myriad other ambiguities might infuriate in a film less ingeniously designed on more tangible fronts. But ''Love'' delights with the detail of its primary set as well as in accomplished effects, consistently interesting yet subservient soundtrack textures (the sole original song is reserved for the closing-credit crawl) and a brisk editorial pace…"{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117944550/ |title=Film Reviews: Love |publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2011-02-10}} Dustin Hucks, for [[Ain't It Cool News]], wrote "''Love'' can at times get very broad with scenes, dialogue, and flow… if you're keen on clarity and the linear, ''Love'' is going to leave you frustrated. For others, however–the challenge of understanding what is what may lead to a desire for repeat viewings, which for me – is a lot of fun… This is a film that's clearly not for everyone – but has a lot to offer the ''[[Inception]]'' and ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'' crowds." Hucks continued to say ''Love'' was one of the most visually exciting low-budget films he'd seen in some time and concluded with an overall endorsement: "''Love'' is well worth seeking out in theaters – but don't miss it on DVD if you don't get the opportunity to view it in theaters."{{cite web |url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/48561 |title=Dustin falls in love with... well, LOVE! |publisher=[[Ain't It Cool News]] |date=2011-02-18 |accessdate=2011-02-20}} ==See also== * ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]'', a 1995 film dramatizing the [[Apollo 13]] incident * ''[[Gravity (film)|Gravity]]'', 2013 3D science-fiction space drama film * ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'', a 2009 British science fiction drama film * [[List of films featuring space stations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Love (2011 film)}} * {{Official website|http://www.angelsandairwaves.com/}} * {{Facebook|id=Love/185669401463186?sk{{=}}wall|name=''Love''}} * {{IMDb title|1541874|Love}} * [https://itunes.apple.com/us/movie/love/id475133903 Love] at the [[iTunes]] Preview * [[File:Emblem CD.png|15x13px|link=DVD|alt=|DVD]] {{UPC|811481012617}} {{Angels & Airwaves}} {{William Eubank}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Love}} [[Category:2010s science fiction films]] [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:American Civil War films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American science fiction films]] [[Category:Dying Earth subgenre]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about astronauts]] [[Category:Films set in 1864]] [[Category:Films set in 2039]] [[Category:Films set in 2045]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] [[Category:Post-apocalyptic films]] [[Category:Films about solitude]] [[Category:Space adventure films]] [[Category:Human extinction]] [[Category:Films directed by William Eubank]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Mercury-Atlas 10 | image = MA-10_Freedom_7-II_Steven_F._Udvar-Hazy_Center_in_Chantilly,_Virginia.JPG | image_caption = | insignia = Freedom 7 II insignia.jpg
| mission_type = Test flight | operator = [[NASA]] | mission_duration = 3 days (planned)
| spacecraft = [[Project Mercury#Spacecraft|Mercury]] No.15 | manufacturer = [[McDonnell Aircraft]] | launch_mass = ~{{convert|3284|lb|kg|disp=flip}}<ref>''Project Mercury quarterly status report no. 19'', p. 4</ref> | landing_mass =
| crew_size = 1 | crew_members = [[Alan Shepard]] | crew_callsign = Freedom 7 II
| launch_date = 1963 (cancelled) | launch_rocket = [[Atlas LV-3B]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 14|LC-14]] }} '''Mercury-Atlas 10''' ('''MA-10''') was a cancelled early [[manned space mission]], which would have been the last flight in [[NASA|NASA's]] [[Mercury program]]. It was planned as a three-day extended mission, to launch in late 1963; the spacecraft, '''''Freedom 7-II''''', would have been flown by [[Alan Shepard]], a veteran of the suborbital [[Mercury-Redstone 3]] mission in 1961. However, it was cancelled after the success of the one-day [[Mercury-Atlas 9]] mission in May 1963, to allow NASA to focus its efforts on the more advanced two-man [[Gemini program]].
==Planning==
Scheduling for the MA-10 mission began as early as mid-1961, before a single orbital flight had been flown. It was planned as a one-day orbital mission, using Spacecraft #15 and Atlas booster 144D.<ref>Grimwood, p. 146</ref> The - by now heavily modified - spacecraft #15A was delivered to Cape Canaveral on 16 November 1962,<ref>Grimwood, p. 177</ref> renumbered #15B in January 1963, and prepared for use as a backup spacecraft for [[Mercury-Atlas 9|MA-9]];<ref>Grimwood, p. 180</ref> by this stage, NASA was noncomittal about whether or not a fifth orbital flight would be flown.<ref>Grimwood, p. 181</ref>
Shortly after the [[Mercury-Atlas 8]] flight in October 1962, some commentators speculated on the possibility of MA-10 being flown as a "dual mission". In this approach, MA-10 and a new MA-11 flight, the latter using the MA-10 backup capsule, would be launched in close proximity, and fly a loosely co-ordinated mission, similar to the Soviet [[Vostok 3]] and [[Vostok 4]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=U.S. Now Has Capability for Twin Space Shot |journal=The Science News-Letter|date=October 20, 1962|volume=82|issue=16|page=254 | jstor = 3944968}}</ref>
While in late 1962 the MA-10 mission had still been planned as a nominal one-day flight,<ref>''Mercury spacecraft no. 15A configuration specification'', p. 1</ref> as of early 1963, the tentative plan for the MA-10 mission anticipated it being around three days long.<ref name="This new ocean, p. 492">''This new ocean'', p. 492</ref> The mission was to be flown by Alan Shepard, the backup pilot for MA-9, then in preparation, and previously the pilot of the [[Mercury-Redstone 3]] suborbital mission in 1961. In a nod to his earlier spacecraft, Shepard named #15B "Freedom 7-II".<ref name="40th">{{cite web |url=https://history.nasa.gov/40thmerc7/shepard.htm |title=Alan B. Shepard, Jr. |accessdate=2009-11-03 |publisher=NASA|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041103035606/https://history.nasa.gov/40thmerc7/shepard.htm|archivedate=2004-11-03}}</ref>
The mission would have carried a re-entry communications experiment, which involved injecting water into the plasma sheath surrounding the spacecraft on reentry, in the hope that it would disrupt the sheath enough to allow radio communications; this was later flown on [[Gemini 3]].<ref>''On the shoulders of titans'', p. 231</ref>
The backup astronaut for Shepard is unclear, but most likely would have been [[Gordon Cooper]], as he was the only other astronaut who had not left the program entirely by mid-1963 or had moved to Gemini.
==Cancellation==
By April, NASA had begun referring to MA-9 as the "culmination" of the program,<ref>Grimwood, p. 188</ref> and on 11 May NASA declared publicly that it was "absolutely beyond question" that a successful MA-9 flight would mean no MA-10.<ref name="This new ocean, p. 492"/> During the MA-9 postflight press conference on 19 May, [[Robert C. Seamans]] was asked about the possibility of a fifth orbital flight, and described it as "quite unlikely". President Kennedy, when asked a similar question three days later, demurred, saying that the decision was one for NASA to make.<ref>Grimwood, p. 194</ref>
A meeting on 6 and 7 June debated carrying on to the MA-10 flight - or possibly beyond. The main argument put forward was that it would gain usable information for the Gemini and Apollo missions without needing a great deal of investment; the spacecraft and launch vehicles were available and almost ready for flight.<ref>Grimwood, pp. 195-196</ref> Pressure had come from a more directly involved constituency as well; both NASA officials and the President himself had been lobbied by the "[[Mercury Seven]]" astronauts for a seventh Mercury mission.<ref name="This new ocean, p. 492"/>
Work continued on modifying Spacecraft #15B until 8 June, but on 12 June, the NASA Administrator, [[James E. Webb]], stated publicly to the Senate Space Committee that there would be no further Mercury flights. All work ceased on the program, with personnel and resources reassigned to the [[Gemini program|Gemini]] and [[Apollo program|Apollo]] programs.<ref>Grimwood, p. 196</ref>
By the summer of 1963, it was obvious that continuing Mercury would sap resources needed for Gemini and Apollo. Despite the ambitious experiments planned for later Mercury missions, they would have run up against the tight payload capacity limits of the capsule and Atlas vehicle. The consumables needed for a three-day Mercury flight alone would have added 100 pounds (136 kilograms) of additional weight. In addition, the large number of malfunctions that occurred on Faith 7's flight drove home the fact that Mercury's hardware wasn't robust enough to stand a day-long mission, let alone multi-day. NASA officials disliked the lengthy gap between manned missions that would result from this decision, and the first manned Gemini mission ended up taking place in March 1965, twenty-two months after the end of Mercury and an even longer amount of time than originally expected.
Four Atlas boosters and Mercury capsules were in a state of partial completion when Mercury was cancelled. Although there was talk of using the leftover Atlases to launch Agena target vehicles for Gemini, the program's funding was eventually increased enough that NASA could afford to buy brand-new Atlases using the newer SLV-3 core.
The capsule was placed in storage, then later displayed at the [[Ames Research Center]] in California; it is now on display at the Smithsonian's [[Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center]] in Chantilly, Virginia.<ref>http://www.nasm.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?id=A19680241000</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==References==
*{{cite book|hdl=2060/19630011968|title=Project Mercury : a chronology|year=1963|last=Grimwood|first=J. M.|publisher=NASA}} [https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4001/cover.htm HTML copy] *{{cite book|hdl=2060/19670005605|title=This new ocean : a history of Project Mercury|year=1966|author1=Alexander, C. C. |author2=Grimwood, J. M. |author3=Swenson, L. S. |publisher=NASA}} [http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4201/cover.htm HTML copy] *{{cite book|hdl=2060/19780012208|title=On the shoulders of titans : a history of Project Gemini|year=1977|author1=Hacker, Barton C. |author2=Grimwood, J. M. |publisher=NASA}} [https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4203/cover.htm HTML copy] *{{cite book|hdl=2060/19730065749|title=Mercury spacecraft no. 15A configuration specification (Mercury-Atlas 10)|date=November 1962|publisher=NASA}} *{{cite book|hdl=2060/19910074178|title=Project Mercury quarterly status report no. 19|year=1963|publisher=NASA}}

The '''Michelangelo Hand''' is a fully articulated robotic [[hand]] [[prosthesis]] developed by the German prosthetics company [[Ottobock]] and its American partner Advanced Arm Dynamics. It is the first prosthesis to feature an electronically actuated [[thumb]] which mimics natural human hand movements.<ref name=ArmDyn>{{cite web |url=http://armdynamics.com/pages/michelangelo |title=Michelangelo Hand |publisher=Advanced Arm Dynamics |accessdate=7 February 2013 }}</ref><ref name=Telegraph>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/9820605/Transplant-patient-receives-bionic-hand-with-electronic-fingers.html |title=Transplant patient receives bionic hand with electronic fingers |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=7 February 2013 }}</ref><ref name=WTHR>{{cite web |url=http://www.wthr.com/story/20111441/indianapolis-minister-first-to-get-revolutionary-prosthetic |title=Indianapolis minister first to get revolutionary prosthetic |publisher=[[WTHR]] |date=15 November 2012 |accessdate=7 February 2013 }}</ref> The Michelangelo Hand can be used for a variety of delicate everyday tasks, was first fitted to an Austrian elective-amputee in July 2010<ref name="DW 2011-07-06">{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.com/en/europes-first-bionic-hand-still-going-strong-a-year-on/a-15213846 |title=Europe's first bionic hand still going strong a year on |author=Sruthi Pinnameneni |publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=6 July 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2018 }}</ref><ref name="Ottobock: Mayrhofer">{{cite web |url=https://www.ottobock.com/en/paralympics/athletes/patrick-mayrhofer/ |title=Patrick Mayrhofer |publisher=[[Ottobock]] |date=13 March 2018<!-- comment in source --> |accessdate=18 March 2018 }}</ref> and has been in use by military and civilian amputees in the United States and United Kingdom since 2011.<ref name=Telegraph/><ref name=WTHR/><ref name=Sing>{{cite web |url=http://singularityhub.com/2012/02/08/man-receives-new-bionic-hand-with-electronic-opposable-thumb/ |title=Man Receives New Bionic Hand With Electronic Opposable Thumb |work=Singularity Hub |date=8 February 2012 |accessdate=7 February 2013 }}</ref>
==Design and development== The Michelangelo Hand's development was begun by the German prosthetics manufacturer Ottobock. In 2008, the American company Advanced Arm Dynamics became involved with testing and further refinement of the prosthesis.<ref name=ArmDyn/>
The prosthesis is battery-powered and can be used for up to 20 hours between charges.<ref name=Telegraph/> Constructed of metal and plastic, it is designed with a natural, [[anthropomorphic]] aesthetic, and can be custom-fitted for each user. Its motions are controlled by built-in [[electrode]]s, which detect the movements of the user's remaining arm muscles and interpret them using [[electromyography]] software.<ref name=ArmDyn/> The fingers can form numerous naturalistic configurations to hold, grip or pinch objects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dukespace.lib.duke.edu/dspace/handle/10161/4718|title=Clinical Experiences With The Michelangelo Hand, A Four-Year Review|author=Miguelez, John M.|year=2011|publisher=[[Duke University]] Libraries|accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref> The Michelangelo Hand is capable of moving with enough precision to conduct delicate tasks such as cooking, [[ironing]] and opening a [[toothpaste]] tube,<ref name=ArmDyn/> but can also exert enough strength to use an automobile's [[steering wheel]]. Skin-toned cosmetic gloves are also available for the prosthesis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hangerclinic.com/limb-loss/adult-upper-extremity/adv-tech/Pages/Michelangelo-Hand.aspx|title=Michelangelo Hand|publisher=Hanger Clinic|year=2014|accessdate=18 April 2015}}</ref> In 2013, the Michelangelo Hand had a unit cost of around £47,000 (US$73,800).<ref name=Telegraph/>
==Users== Austrian electrician [[Patrick Mayrhofer]] suffered serious injuries to his hands at the age of 20 when he touched a [[electric power transmission|6000-volt power line]] in February 2008. After unsuccessful attempts to reconstruct his left hand, it was [[amputation|amputated]] below the elbow in July 2010<ref name="Paralympic biography 2018">{{cite web |url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/PWG2018/en/snowboard/athlete-profile-n3047895-patrick-mayrhofer.htm |title=Athlete Profile — Patrick MAYRHOFER |publisher=[[PyeongChang Organizing Committee for the 2018 Olympic & Paralympic Winter Games]] |date= |accessdate=18 March 2018 }}</ref> and he became the first patient in the world to be fitted with a Michelangelo Hand.<ref name="DW 2011-07-06"/><ref name="Ottobock: Mayrhofer"/><ref name="Behindertensportler des Jahres">{{cite news |url=https://www.meinbezirk.at/rohrbach/sport/mayrhofer-ist-behindertensportler-des-jahres-d1533244.html |title=Mayrhofer ist Behindertensportler des Jahres |work=MeinBezirk.at |date=4 November 2015 |accessdate=19 March 2018 |language=de }}</ref><ref name="BBC 2011-05-18">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-13273348 |title=Bionic hand for 'elective amputation' patient |author=Neil Bowdler |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2018 }}</ref> He joined Ottobock 3 years later, helping their customers learn to use their prostheses.<ref name="Cybathlon">{{cite web |url=http://www.cybathlon.ethz.ch/cybathlon-news/2015/06/pilots-of-the-cyathlon-patrick-mayrhofer.html |title=Pilots of the Cybathlon: Patrick Mayrhofer |publisher=Cybathlon, [[ETH Zurich]] |date=5 June 2015 |accessdate=20 March 2018 }}</ref> Having started [[para-snowboarding]] in 2012,<ref name="Ottobock: Mayrhofer"/><ref name="Paralympic biography 2018"/> Mayrhofer was named Paralympic [[Austrian Sports Personality of the Year]]<ref name="Behindertensportler des Jahres"/> after winning a gold medal in [[banked slalom]] at the 2015 [[Para-Snowboard World Championships]]<ref name="WC2015 banked slalom">{{cite web |url=https://www.paralympic.org/sdms/web/calendar/sb/result/SBWI15SBMBSL01010000100 |title=2015 IPCAS Para Snowboard World Championships La Molina: Men's banked slalom SB-UL |publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]] |date=28 February 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2015 }}</ref> He went on to win the Paralympic silver medal in [[snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Paralympics – Men's banked slalom|banked slalom]] at the [[2018 Winter Olympics]].<ref name="2018 Paralympics banked slalom">{{cite web |url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/PWG2018/en/snowboard/medals-and-ranking-men-s-banked-slalom-sb-ul.htm |title=Medals and Ranking — Men's Banked Slalom SB-UL |publisher=[[PyeongChang Organizing Committee for the 2018 Olympic & Paralympic Winter Games]] |date=16 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018 }}</ref>
Numerous American soldiers who suffered limb amputation in combat have received Michelangelo Hands since 2011. In January 2012, Matt Rezink of [[Wisconsin]] became the first American civilian to receive a unit.<ref name=Sing/> In January 2013, Chris Taylor, a British service engineer who had lost his right hand in a [[jet ski]] accident in 2009, became the first UK citizen to be fitted with a Michelangelo Hand.<ref name=Telegraph/> By 2013, the hand was offered by several British prosthetic services companies, including Dorset Orthopaedic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dorset-ortho.com/prosthetics/prosthetic-limbs/michelangelo-hand/|title=Michelangelo Hand by Otto Bock|publisher=Dorset Orthopaedic|accessdate=11 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111090753/http://www.dorset-ortho.com/prosthetics/prosthetic-limbs/michelangelo-hand/|archivedate=11 November 2013|df=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Boston Digital Arm]], an American manufacturer of powered prostheses
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://armdynamics.com/pages/michelangelo Advanced Arm Dynamics website] *[http://www.living-with-michelangelo.com/gb/home/ Otto Bock Michelangelo page]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Missouri State Senators to [[:Category:Missouri state senators]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 17]].
revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=October 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = [[Brigadier general|Brigadier-General]] | name = Mosby Monroe Parsons | image = MMParsons.jpg | caption = photographed in the early 1860s | birth_date = May 21, 1822 | birth_place = [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] | death_date = August 15, 1865 | death_place = Near [[Camargo Municipality, Tamaulipas|Camargo]], [[Mexico]] | allegiance = {{unbulleted list|{{flag|United States|1848}}|[[Confederate government of Missouri|Missouri]]|{{flag|Confederate States|1865}}}} | branch = {{unbulleted list|[[United States Volunteers]]|[[File:Flag of the Missouri State Guard.svg|Missouri|border|23px]] [[Missouri State Guard]]|{{army|CSA|size=23px}}}} | serviceyears = {{unbulleted list|1846–1848 (USV)|1861–1862 (MSG)|1862–1865 (CSA)}} | rank = {{unbulleted list|[[File:Union army cpt rank insignia.jpg|30px]] [[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]] (USV)|[[File:Union army brig gen rank insignia.jpg|30px]] [[Brigadier general|Brigadier-General]] (MSG)|[[File:Confederate States of America General.png|30px]] [[Brigadier general|Brigadier-General]] (CSA)}} | commands = | battles = '''[[Mexican–American War]]'''
*[[Battle of El Brazito]] *[[Battle of the Sacramento River]] '''[[American Civil War]]''' *[[Battle of Carthage (1861)]] *[[Battle of Wilson's Creek]] *[[Battle of Pea Ridge]] *[[Battle of Prairie Grove]] *[[Battle of Helena]] *[[Battle of Jenkins' Ferry]] '''[[Second French intervention in Mexico]]'''{{KIA}} }} '''Mosby Monroe Parsons''' (May 21, 1822 – August 15, 1865) was a senior [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]] of the [[Missouri State Guard]] and the [[Confederate States Army]] who commanded [[infantry]] in the [[Trans-Mississippi Theater of the American Civil War]]. ==Early life and career== The eldest child of Gustavus Adolphus Parsons and his wife Patience Monroe Bishop, Mosby Monroe Parsons was born in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. When he was 13, his parents moved to [[Cole County, Missouri]]. Two years later, they moved again to [[Jefferson City]], which Parsons would thereafter make his home. As a young man, Mosby [[read law]] and was admitted to the bar in 1846. He served as a volunteer in the [[Mexican-American War]] with the rank of captain in Colonel [[Alexander W. Doniphan]]'s regiment and was cited for gallantry at the [[Battle of Sacramento]] on February 28, 1847. Returning to Missouri after the war, he married Mary Wells on September 18, 1850. However, his wife died just three years later, leaving him with an infant son, Stephen Kearney Parsons. Parsons served as the United States [[District Attorney]] for western Missouri. In 1856 was elected to the state legislature. He became a state senator in 1858, serving until the Civil War began in early 1861. ==American Civil War== During the [[secession crisis]] in Missouri, Parsons was appointed brigadier general in command of the Sixth Division of the [[Missouri State Guard]]. He arrived too late to participate in the skirmish at [[Battle of Boonville|Boonville]], but he went on to lead his division at [[Battle of Carthage (1861)|Carthage]] and the [[Battle of Wilson's Creek]] in Missouri. Although his Missouri State Guardsmen participated in the [[Battle of Pea Ridge]] in [[Arkansas in the American Civil War|Arkansas]], Parsons was absent from this action seeking an appointment into the Confederate Army in Richmond, Virginia. Parsons was commissioned a brigadier general of the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]] on November 5, 1862 and led his infantry brigade in the [[Battle of Prairie Grove]], Arkansas one month later. His force would participate in the attack at [[Helena, Arkansas|Helena]], Arkansas on July 4, 1863, and assisted [[Richard Taylor (general)|Richard Taylor]] in thwarting [[Union Army|Union]] [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[Nathaniel Banks|Nathaniel Banks's]] [[Red River Campaign]] of 1864 in Louisiana (Battle of Pleasant Hill), as well as opposing Union Major General [[Frederick Steele]]'s [[Camden Expedition]] in Arkansas, including participation at the [[Battle of Jenkins' Ferry]]. Parsons was appointed a major general by Trans-Mississippi Departmental Commander [[Kirby Smith]] on April 30, 1864, although his promotion was never confirmed by [[Jefferson Davis]]. ==Death== After the war's end, Parsons, like many other Missouri Confederates, chose to go to [[Mexico]] rather than return to Missouri. He and three companions, including his brother-in-law, Capt. Austin M. Standish, Standish's orderly William "Dutch Bill" Wenderling [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87052143/1886-01-30/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=1865&index=3&rows=20&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&words=Aaron+Conrow+H&proxdistance=5&date2=1922&ortext=&proxtext=aaron+H+Conrow&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 Lexington Weekly Intelligencer January 30, 1886 accessed March 24, 2016 Library of Congress] and former [[Confederate Congress]]man [[Aaron H. Conrow]] were attacked, captured, and executed by a band of regular Mexican cavalry near [[China, Mexico]] headed for [[Camargo Municipality, Tamaulipas]] on August 15, 1865.[http://muse.jhu.edu/chapter/1684593 Gurley, Bill J. "Mosby Monroe Parsons: Major General, Murder Victim"] in "Confederate Generals in the Trans-Mississippi, Volume 2." Knoxville, Tennessee, University of Tennessee Press, 2015. {{ISBN|978-1-62190-124-2}}. pp. 209-210. Retrieved June 3, 2016. Via [[Project Muse]] (subscription required). The bodies of Parsons and his comrades were either thrown into the San Juan River or buried in unmarked graves where they were killed. In 1868, Parsons's son (Kearny Parsons) and sister (Mildred Standish), along with the family of Aaron Conrow, sued the Mexican government via the U.S. and Mexico Claims Commission Convention. In 1875, a judgment in the amount of almost $50,000.00 in gold was awarded to each of the plaintiffs. ==See also== *[[List of American Civil War generals (Confederate)]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Gurley, Bill J. "Mosby Monroe Parsons: Missouri's Forgotten Brigadier" in "Confederate Generals in the Trans-Mississippi, Volume 1." Knoxville, Tennessee, University of Tennessee Press, 2013. {{ISBN|978-1572338661}}. * Gurley, Bill J. "Mosby Monroe Parsons: Major General, Murder Victim" in "Confederate Generals in the Trans-Mississippi, Volume 2." Knoxville, Tennessee, University of Tennessee Press, 2015. {{ISBN|978-1621900894}}. * Hinze, David; Farnham, Karen, ''The Battle of Carthage, Border War in Southwest Missouri, July 5, 1861.'' Gretna, Louisiana: Pelican Publishing, 2004. {{ISBN|1-58980-223-3}}. * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. * Sifakis, Stewart. ''Who Was Who in the Civil War.'' New York: Facts On File, 1988. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-1055-4}}. * [[Ezra J. Warner (historian)|Warner, Ezra J.]] ''Generals in Gray: Lives of the Confederate Commanders.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1959. {{ISBN|978-0-8071-0823-9}}. ==External links== * [http://www.missouridivision-scv.org/camp718.php Brig. Gen. Mosby Monroe Parsons Camp No. 718] of the [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]] * [http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~wfbishop/oldversion/friendsbishopgenealogy/missouri/obituary/moobi258.htm#Mos Mosby Monroe Parsons] at [[Ancestry.com]] * [http://mohistory.org/files/archives_guides/ParsonsMosby.pdf Mosby Monroe Parsons Papers] at the [[Missouri History Museum]]
{{Missouri in the Civil War|state=expanded}} {{Portalbar|American Civil War|Biography|Missouri|Politics}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Parsons, Mosby Monroe}} [[Category:1822 births]] [[Category:1865 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American lawyers]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American lawyers admitted to the practice of law by reading law]] [[Category:American expatriates in Mexico]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Mexican–American War]] [[Category:American refugees]] [[Category:Confederate States Army brigadier generals]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Mexico]] [[Category:Members of the Missouri House of Representatives]] [[Category:Missouri Democrats]] [[Category:Missouri lawyers]] [[Category:Missouri State Guard]] [[Category:Missouri state senators]] [[Category:People declared dead in absentia]] [[Category:People from Charlottesville, Virginia]] [[Category:People from Jefferson City, Missouri]] [[Category:People of Missouri in the American Civil War]] [[Category:Refugees in Mexico]] [[Category:United States Attorneys for the Western District of Missouri]]

revision.comment: /* Lost inquest file */Inyama was told to give the case away. He did not do so of his own accord.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Alice Gross | image = Alice Gross.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = {{nowrap|Alice Poppy Madeleine Gross}}{{cite web|url=http://alice.poppymadeleine.gross.muchloved.com/frame.aspx?df=false|title=Alice’s Youth Music Memorial Fund|website=Alice’s Youth Music Memorial Fund}} | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|2000|2|14}}{{cite web|url=http://alice.poppymadeleine.gross.muchloved.com/|title=Alice’s Youth Music Memorial Fund|website=Alice’s Youth Music Memorial Fund}} | birth_place = [[London]], England | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|df=yes|2014|8|28|2000|2|14}} | disappeared_place = London, England{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-29251735|title=Alice Gross disappearance: Suspect murdered wife in Latvia|date=18 September 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} | death_cause = Homicide by asphyxiation{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/alice-gross-murder-review-inquiry-river-brent-arnis-zalkalns|title=What we know about the murder of Alice Gross|publisher=}} | body_discovered = 30 September 2014
[[River Brent]], London, England | known_for = Homicide victim }} '''Alice Poppy Madeleine Gross''' (14 February 2000 – {{Circa}} 28 August 2014) was an English girl who was murdered in London. Gross suffered from [[anorexia nervosa|anorexia]], which was suggested by her mother and some mainstream media sources in the early days of the search for her as being related to her disappearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/crime/article4197125.ece|title=Missing Alice has anorexia, police reveal|first=Gabriella|last=Swerling|publisher=}} She lived in [[Hanwell]], west London, with her sister, Nina Gross,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-29471094|title=Question Time apologises over Alice immigration debate|date=3 October 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} and parents,{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/alice-gross-police-release-cctv-footage-of-teenager-as-parents-appeal-for-her-safe-return-9713701.html|title=Alice Gross: Police release CCTV footage of teenager as parents appeal for her safe return|work=The Independent|accessdate=21 September 2014|date=5 September 2014|author=Natasha Culzac}} Jose Gross and Rosalind Hodgkiss. She went missing after leaving her home in Hanwell on 28 August 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/oct/01/alice-gross-police-find-body-river-brent|title=Police searching for missing teenager Alice Gross find body in the river Brent|first1=Vikram|last1=Dodd|first2=Chris|last2=Johnston|first3=|last3=agencies|date=1 October 2014|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} The search for her was the largest deployment of [[Metropolitan Police]] officers in a search operation since the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]].{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1339183/alice-gross-police-search-is-largest-since-7-7|title=Alice Gross Police Search Is Largest Since 7/7|work=Sky News|accessdate=21 September 2014|date=20 September 2014|author=Tom Parmenter}} It involved 600 officers from eight forces.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-29293080|title=Alice Gross disappearance: Search 'largest since 7/7'|work=BBC News|accessdate=21 September 2014|date=20 September 2014}} Gross's body was found in the [[River Brent]] five weeks later, on 30 September. ==Suspects== Two men were arrested in connection with Gross's death; both were later released without charge.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/sep/16/alice-gross-police-missing-latvian|title=Alice Gross disappearance: police search for missing man|work=The Guardian|accessdate=21 September 2014|date=16 September 2014}} The [[prime suspect]] was [[Latvians|Latvian]] builder and convicted murderer Arnis Zalkalns, who went missing from [[Ealing]], London, on 3 September. ==Murder inquiry== On 1 October, police launched a murder inquiry after Gross's body was found hidden under logs on the bed of the [[River Brent]] the night before.{{cite news|title=Body found in river is Alice Gross, police confirm|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/oct/01/body-found-river-alice-gross-police|accessdate=1 October 2014|work=The Guardian|date=1 October 2014}} On 4 October, police announced that they had found a badly decomposed body in dense woodland in [[Boston Manor Park]] during their search for Zalkalns, and that early indications suggested the body may be his.{{cite news|title=Body found in Alice Gross suspect search|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-29492356|accessdate=4 October 2014|publisher=BBC News|date=4 October 2014}} Police confirmed two days later that the body was that of Zalkalns. The cause of his death was hanging.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-29515913|publisher=BBC|title=Alice Gross death: Body found is suspect Arnis Zalkalns|work=BBC News|date=6 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014}} ==Community involvement== The local community of Hanwell was galvanised during the time Gross was missing, and a poster campaign to “Find Alice” was organised through a [[Facebook]] page. In order to increase public awareness of Gross being missing the community tied yellow ribbons to trees, railings, their cars and homes. On 8 October Gross's family requested that the ribbons be removed while memorials were left at the Clock Tower in Hanwell. Ealing Borough Council flew flags at half-mast following the discovery of Gross's body, opened a public book of condolence and replanted flower beds near to the Hanwell Clock Tower with yellow pansies in Gross's memory. ==Police briefing== In a briefing on 28 January 2015, the Metropolitan Police stated that "all the evidence points firmly to Arnis Zalkalns" and that he would have been charged if he had not hanged himself.[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]], p.20, 28 January 2015 ==Lost inquest file== On 26 July 2015, it was reported that a 30-page document relating to the case had been lost after West London coroner Chinyere Inyama left it on a train.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-33668112 |title=Alice Gross murder file lost in coroner error |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=26 July 2015 |accessdate=26 July 2015}}{{cite news|first=Caroline |last=Davies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/jul/26/alice-gross-investigation-coroner-file-train-chinyere-inyama |title=Alice Gross: investigation launched after coroner leaves sensitive file on train |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=26 July 2015 |accessdate=26 July 2015}} Inyama subsequently was told to reassigned the case to another coroner, and it was taken by Dr Fiona Wilcox.{{Cite news|url = |title = Alice Gross coroner drops out of murder inquest after he leaves police file on train|last = Watts|first = Matt|date = 9 October 2015|work = London Evening Standard|access-date = |via = |page = 7}} == References == {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gross, Alice}} [[Category:2000 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:English children]] [[Category:English victims of crime]] [[Category:People from Hanwell]] [[Category:2014 in London]] [[Category:2010s missing person cases]] [[Category:2014 crimes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:History of the London Borough of Ealing]]

revision.text:
The '''Murder of Brian Glick''' involved [[homicide]] victim Brian Glick, who was murdered at the age of 21 on October 25, 1993, by Dennis Tate and Michael Olson in [[Bloomington, Minnesota|Bloomington]], [[Minnesota]]. Glick's murder was a shock to the [[Minneapolis-Saint Paul|Twin Cities]] community, and his death and the subsequent court proceedings of his murderers received widespread attention in the Twin Cities press.
==Brian Glick's life== Brian Glick was born on April 25, 1972, in [[Duluth, Minnesota]]. He grew up in [[Minneapolis]]. His parents were divorced in 1978. His family moved to Bloomington and in 1990 Glick graduated from [[Bloomington Kennedy High School]]. In 1992 he began working at a [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]] store on Old Shakopee Road East, a block away from where he lived with his mother, stepfather and teenage sister, Tammy. At the time of his death Glick had been working to save enough money to marry his fiancée Katie Long.<ref name=Employee>Neal Gendler. "Employee alone in store robbed, beaten to death in Bloomington." Star Tribune. 27 Oct, 1993</ref> Glick was interested in [[aviation]], but his plans to become an aircraft mechanic were thwarted when it was discovered that he was [[color-blind]]. Instead, Glick returned to school and completed the necessary course work to become a paramedic.<ref name=Employee/>
In the year before his death, it was discovered that Glick had a large [[benign]] [[brain tumor]], and in May 1992 he underwent surgery to have it removed.<ref name= Wangstad>Wayne Wangstad. "Clues Sought In Beating Of Bloomington Man." St. Paul Pioneer Press. 27 Oct. 1993.</ref> At the time of his death Glick was still recovering, but his prognosis was positive. However, the operation that saved his life contributed to his death. Shortly after surgery Glick returned to work at Subway. On the last day his boss saw him he commented "You're really bouncing around here tonight. You really look good." Glick responded that he was feeling the best he had since the surgery and he was going to make it.<ref name=Margaret>Zack Margaret. "Man Gets 27 Years for Murdering Subway Employee." Star Tribune 25 Mar. 1994.</ref>
==The murder== On the night of Monday October 25, 1993, Glick was working alone at the Subway shop. He spoke with his fiancée by telephone around 11 p.m., and fifteen minutes later, at around 11:15 p.m., went out back to empty the trash.<ref name=Man>"Man, 19, is indicted in Subway shop killing." Star Tribune. 25 Nov. 1993.</ref> Glick was unaware that Dennis Tate (b. 04/27/1977), 16,<ref name= Tatecr>{{cite court |litigants= State of Minnesota vs Mujahid Ghazi Muhammad. Case No. 27-CR-94-011109. |vol= |reporter= |opinion= |pinpoint= |court= Hennepin County District Court |date= 11/24/1993|url= http://pa.courts.state.mn.us/default.aspx |accessdate=May 7, 2016 |quote=}} Note: In order to access the records, search by name or case number in the Criminal/Traffic/Petty Case Records database.</ref> and Michael William Olson (b. 03/05/1974), 19,<ref name= Olsoncr>{{cite court |litigants= State of Minnesota vs Michael William Olson. Case No. 27-CR-93-095676. |vol= |reporter= |opinion= |pinpoint= |court= Hennepin County District Court |date= 10/29/1993 |url= http://pa.courts.state.mn.us/default.aspx |accessdate=May 7, 2016 |quote=}} Note: In order to access the records, search by name or case number in the Criminal/Traffic/Petty Case Records database.</ref> were waiting for him behind the store. Olson was a former employee at the store, but had been fired, and knew both Glick and the layout of the store.<ref name=Man/> As Glick headed back into the shop after emptying the trash, Tate and Olson jumped him and brutally choked and beat him until he was unrecognizable.<ref name= Sweeney>Mike Sweeney. "Suspects Admit Sandwich Shop Slaying." St. Paul Pioneer Press. 30 Oct. 1993.</ref> The two then entered the store, vandalized surveillance cameras, and stole a cashbox containing $152. Glick's fiancée went to the store about 11:30 p.m. to pick him up. When she found the store empty she called police, who arrived shortly before midnight. Glick was found behind the store and immediately taken by ambulance to [[Hennepin County Medical Center]].<ref name=Gendler>Neal Gendler. "2 Juveniles Are Charged With Murder In Unrelated Stabbing, Beating Deaths." Star Tribune 02 Nov. 1993.</ref> Glick died at 4:50 a.m. Tuesday, October 26, 1993, with his parents at his bedside. Doctors noted that a piece of skull that was healing from the recent brain tumor operation had been pushed up and back into his brain, contributing to Glick's death.<ref name= Wangstad/>
==The convictions and releases== Michael Olson was arrested on October 27 after police found a bloody shirt at his home.<ref name=Sweeney/> Dennis Tate was apprehended the following day. The two confessed to killing Glick, and told the police that they had intended to double the money stolen with the purchase and sale of drugs - a plan that went awry when they were ripped off by a drug dealer.<ref name=Sub>Wayne Wangstad. "Sub shop slaying suspects wanted to double money." St. Paul Pioneer Press 29 Oct, 1993.</ref>
Olson and Tate pleaded guilty in a [[Hennepin County Government Center|Hennepin County District Court]]. Olson's proceedings were overseen by Judge [[Kevin Burke, Judge|Kevin Burke]].<ref name=Margaret/><ref name= Tatecr/><ref name= Olsoncr/> Olson was sentenced in March 1994 to 27 years and two months in prison for [[second-degree murder]].<ref name=Margaret/><ref name= Olsoncr/> Glick's father, Stephen; mother; and fiancée provided victim statements at the proceedings. At Olson's [[Sentence (law)|sentencing]] Glick's father said:
{{quote|His [Olson's] prison is now measured by walls. Mine is measured in sadness, loneliness and anger. For the rest of my life, my relationship with my son has been dictated by him. I hate him for making this prison for me. I hate him for taking it upon himself to decide how I will relate to my son.<ref name=Margaret/>}}
Tate's proceedings took over a year because his defense argued he was not yet sixteen years old, even though a birth certificate showed he was born over sixteen years ago, and therefore he could not be tried as an adult. The motion was denied by the judge, but Tate's team appealed the conviction all the way to Minnesota Supreme Court, which denied Tate's petition. Tate was ordered to stand trial as an adult, but he pleaded guilty to second-degree murder. In January 1995, Tate was sentenced to 25½ years in prison by Judge John M. Stanoch.<ref name= Tatecr/><ref name=Parsons>Jim Parsons. "Surprise speaker makes race issue - Murder victim's parents irate in court." Star Tribune 31 Jan. 1995.</ref> At Tate's sentencing, Minneapolis Imam Matthew Ramadan spoke on Tate's behalf and stated Tate's fate was "the same situation of so many other African-American males. I expect the courts to judge him more harshly because he killed a white man. Justice is not blind." Glick's exasperated mother was quoted in the [[Star Tribune]] saying, "I'm the one who lost a son. Why did he [Ramadan] try to turn it into a racial thing?"<ref name=Parsons/>
While in prison, Tate changed his name to Mujahid Ghazi Muhammad. He was released from prison under supervised custody in a work release program in [[Ramsey County, Minnesota|Ramsey County]] in 2010. <ref name= Tatecr/><ref name=vinetate>Mujahid Ghazi Muhammad. [https://www.vinelink.com/vinelink/siteInfoAction.do?siteId=24002 https://www.vinelink.com/vinelink/siteInfoAction.do?siteId=24002]. Offender ID:180694. Note: To find the document, you must manually search the site using first or last name or offender ID number.</ref><ref name=corrtate>{{cite web |url=http://www.doc.state.mn.us/publicviewer/Inmate.asp?OID=180694 |title=Mujahid Ghazi Muhammad |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=doc.state.mn.us |publisher=[[Minnesota Department of Corrections]] |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref>
In 2011 Olson was released from prison under supervised custody in a work release program in Hennepin County.<ref name=corrolson>{{cite web |url=http://www.doc.state.mn.us/publicviewer/Inmate.asp?OID=175935 |title=Michael William Olson |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=doc.state.mn.us |publisher=[[Minnesota Department of Corrections]] |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Glick, Brian}} [[Category:1993 murders in the United States]] [[Category:American murder victims]] [[Category:Murder committed by minors]] [[Category:People murdered in Minnesota]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by beating in the United States]] [[Category:1993 in Minnesota]] [[Category:October 1993 events]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person |name= Polly Klaas |image= Polly Klaas.jpg |image_caption= |birth_name= Polly Hannah Klaas |birth_date= {{birth date|1981|01|03}} |birth_place= [[Fairfax, California]], [[United States]] |death_date={{Death date and age|1993|10|01|1981|01|03}} |death_place= [[Petaluma, California]], [[United States]] |body_discovered= December 4, 1993 |death_cause= Strangulation |nationality= [[United States|American]] |citizenship= [[United States]] |occupation= Student |known_for= Murder victim |website= [http://www.pollyklaas.org/ pollyklaas.org] }} '''Polly Hannah Klaas''' (January 3, 1981 – October 1, 1993) was an American murder victim whose case gained national attention. On October 1, 1993, at the age of twelve, she was [[kidnapping|kidnapped]] at knife point during a [[slumber party]] from her mother's home in [[Petaluma, California]]. She was later strangled. [[Richard Allen Davis]] was convicted of her murder in 1996 and [[capital punishment|sentenced to death]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/polly-smiling-killer-death-sentence-article-1.741066|title=Polly's Smiling Killer Gets Death Sentence|last=Kennedy|first=Helen|date=August 6, 1996|publisher=''The New York Daily News''|accessdate=January 28, 2009}}</ref>
==Background== On October 1, 1993, Polly Klaas and two friends were having a slumber party. Late in the evening, [[Richard Allen Davis]] entered their bedroom, carrying a knife. He tied both friends up, pulled pillowcases over their heads and told them to count to 1,000. He then kidnapped Klaas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pollyklaas.org/about/pollys-story.html|title=Polly's Story|work=pollyklaas.org}}</ref>
Over the next two months, about 4,000 people helped search for Klaas.<ref name="Mercury News">{{cite news|last1=Howe|first1=Kevin|title=City nearly demolishes Polly Klaas bench in Pacific Grove – The Mercury News|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2011/09/15/city-nearly-demolishes-polly-klaas-bench-in-pacific-grove/|accessdate=April 24, 2017|work=MediaNews, Monterey County Herald|publisher=The Mercury News|date=August 13, 2016}}</ref> TV shows such as ''[[20/20 (US television show)|20/20]]'' and ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'' covered the kidnapping. An APB ([[all-points bulletin]]) with the suspect's information was broadcast within 30 minutes of the kidnapping. The broadcast, however, only went out over Sonoma County Sheriff's Channel 1.
In a rural area of Santa Rosa, about 20 miles north of Petaluma, a babysitter on her way home noted a suspicious vehicle stuck in a ditch on her employer's private driveway. She phoned the property owner, who decided to leave with her daughter. As she drove down the long driveway to Pythian Road, the owner passed Davis. She called 911 when she got to a service station and two deputies were dispatched on the call. The deputies did not know of the kidnapping or the suspect's description, due to Sonoma Valley units being on Channel 3. The deputies ran Davis' driver's license and license plate number, but they came back with no wants or warrants. The deputies tried to convince the property owner to perform a [[citizen's arrest]] for trespassing. Under California law, a citizen may make an arrest for this type of misdemeanor. The property owner would have had to go to the car with the deputies and say "I arrest you." The deputies then would have taken Davis into custody. The property owner refused.
The deputies called for a tow truck to get Davis' car out of the ditch. They searched it thoroughly before the arrival of the tow truck and did not find evidence of anyone else in the car. The only possible violation was an open container of beer, but Davis was not driving at the time of the deputies' contact and mere possession of an open container was not illegal. Before Davis was allowed to leave, he was instructed to pour out the beer and the deputies filled out an FI (Field Interrogation) card with his information and the FI card was filed.
On November 28, 1993, the property owner was inspecting her property after loggers had partially cleared the property of trees. She discovered items that made her think they might have matched those used in the kidnapping. She called the sheriff's department to report her discovery, and deputies and crime scene investigators were dispatched. One of the items found, a torn pair of ballet leggings, was matched by the FBI Crime Laboratory to the other part of the leggings that were taken as evidence on the night of the kidnapping. A review of calls in the area the day of the kidnapping turned up the contact with Davis, who had only been identified because both deputies had filled out and filed the FI card. Once the identity of Davis was revealed, his palm print at the scene of the kidnapping was also traced to him. Authorities had been unable to match the partial print earlier due to the poor quality of the print.
The Sonoma County Sheriff's Department, in cooperation with Petaluma Police and the FBI, launched a search of the property and the Pythian Road area during a heavy rainstorm. The first two days of the search were kept as low-key as possible, since Davis was under surveillance at an Indian rancheria near Ukiah, California. When nothing was found during the initial search and the surveillance of Davis also produced no results, the decision was made to arrest him for the kidnapping of Klaas.
While Davis was being interrogated by Petaluma PD and the FBI, a massive search was launched on Friday, December 3. The Sonoma County Sheriff's Department was assisted by over 500 search team members from 24 agencies, coming from as far away as Kern County, California and Washoe County, Nevada. The mutual aid effort was coordinated by the California State Office of Emergency Services (now known as the [[California Governor's Office of Emergency Services]]), FBI Crime Scene teams and numerous other state and federal agencies. The search remains today as one of the largest ever conducted in California. The search continued through Saturday, December 4. The search effort produced other items of evidence, but did not produce any evidence of human remains. The search was planned to continue on Sunday, December 5, but on the evening of December 4, Davis confessed to kidnapping and murdering Klaas and led investigators to her body.<ref name="LA Times">{{cite news|title=Graphic Testimony in Klaas Trial Forces Family Out of Court|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-05-07/news/mn-1395_1_family-klaas-trial|accessdate=April 24, 2017|work=Associated Press|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=May 7, 1996|location=San Jose, CA.}}</ref> He had buried her in a shallow grave just off Highway 101, about a mile south of the city limits of [[Cloverdale, California]]. The grave site is about 20 air miles and about 30 road miles from the search site.
Although Davis admitted to strangling Klaas to death, he refused to give investigators a timeline of the events from October 1. Investigators thought he was fearful that both people who passed him would call the sheriff's department. It is believed that he killed her before the arrival of deputies and hid her body in the thick brush on the hillside above where his car was stuck. He then waited for an undetermined period of time after being escorted back to Highway 12, about 1.5 miles from where his car was stuck and drove back up to retrieve her body. He was reportedly out of breath, sweating profusely (despite being a cool night) and had twigs and leaves in his hair when contacted by deputies. It is also believed that he had chosen the grave site in advance, since it would not have been discovered by a casual observer. The gravesite area would be directly visible from Highway 101, but not the grave itself. He had to drive from the Indian Rancheria in Ukiah once a week to meet with his parole officer and he would have seen any police activity in the area.
==Conviction== After a long, tumultuous trial, Davis was convicted on June 18, 1996, of first-degree murder and four special circumstances (robbery, burglary, kidnapping and a lewd act on a child) in Klaas' death.<ref name=townhall>{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/columnists/debrajsaunders/2009/03/12/richard_allen_davis_safe_on_death_row/page/full/|title=Richard Allen Davis: Safe on Death Row|work=townhall.com}}</ref> A [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] Superior Court jury returned a verdict of death. At his formal sentencing by a judge, Davis provoked national outrage by taunting his victim's family, extending both middle fingers at a courtroom camera<ref name="south coast today">{{cite news|last1=Locke|first1=Michelle|title=The Polly Klaas story unfolded through a veil of many tears|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/19960811/NEWS/308119990|accessdate=April 24, 2017|work=Associated Press|publisher=southcoasttoday.com|date=August 11, 1996|location=SAN JOSE, Calif.|language=en}}</ref> and later saying that Klaas' last words just before he killed her were that her father molested her.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/27/us/before-being-sentenced-to-die-killer-disrupts-a-courtroom.html|title=Before Being Sentenced to Die, Killer Disrupts a Courtroom|date=September 27, 1996|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=December 5, 2017|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref> Judge Thomas Hastings sentenced Davis to death by lethal injection<ref name="NY Daily News">{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Helen|title=POLLY'S SMILING KILLER GETS DEATH SENTENCE|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/polly-smiling-killer-death-sentence-article-1.741066|accessdate=April 24, 2017|work=NY Daily News|date=August 6, 1996|language=en}}</ref> and remarked, "It is very easy for me to pronounce this sentence, given your revolting behavior in this courtroom".
Davis is currently on death row at [[San Quentin State Prison]], in Marin County, California. Having survived an apparent drug overdose while in prison and attacks on him by several other prisoners, Davis is now in solitary confinement and continues to assist his attorneys in various appeals, and has more appeals ahead of him before the sentence passed can be carried out.
==Winona Ryder== Actress [[Winona Ryder]], who had been raised in Petaluma, offered a $200,000 reward for Klaas' safe return during the search. After her death, Ryder starred in a [[Little Women (1994 film)|film version]] of ''[[Little Women]]'' and dedicated it to her memory, because that had been her favorite book.<ref>[http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,301373,00.html 'Women' on the Verge]; last accessed December 31, 2007.</ref>
==Aftermath and legacy== Klaas' body was cremated and her ashes spread over the [[Pacific Ocean]] by her friends and family.
In the wake of the murder, Klaas' father, Marc Klaas, became a child advocate and established the [[Polly Klaas Foundation#KlaasKids Foundation|KlaasKids Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wbko.com/tech/headlines/22214009.html |title=WBKO Talks With Child Advocate Marc Klaas About KlaasKids Foundation |last=Provenzano |first=Sam |date=June 27, 2008 |publisher=wbko.com |accessdate=January 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006064801/http://www.wbko.com/tech/headlines/22214009.html |archivedate=October 6, 2008 }}</ref> He has made himself available to parents of kidnapped children and has appeared frequently on ''[[Larry King Live]]'', ''[[CNN Headline News]]'' and ''[[Nancy Grace (TV series)|Nancy Grace]]''. He is also portrayed in ''[[The Elizabeth Smart Story]]'' by Barry Flatman, as meeting the Smarts and informing them he was working with [[Fox News]].
The all points bulletin was broadcast on the CHP ([[California Highway Patrol]]) channel, which only CHP radios could receive. CHP practice changed after the case. The radio system was upgraded and such bulletins are now broadcast on all police channels through a centralized 911 dispatch system.
Five years after Klaas' murder, a performing arts center was named in her honor in Petaluma.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sfchroniclemarketplace.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1998/10/01/NEWS556.dtl&hw=petaluma&sn=189&sc=241|title=Performing arts center dedicated to Polly Klaas|date=October 1, 1998|publisher=sfchroniclemarketplace.com|accessdate=January 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207183808/http://sfchroniclemarketplace.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fe%2Fa%2F1998%2F10%2F01%2FNEWS556.dtl&hw=petaluma&sn=189&sc=241|archivedate=February 7, 2009|df=}}</ref>
In the wake of the murder, politicians in California and other U.S. states supported [[three strikes law]]s and California's Three Strikes act was signed into law on March 8, 1994.<ref>{{cite news|last1=George|first1=Evan|title=Prop. 36 and how California's 'Three Strikes' law came to be|url=http://curious.kcrw.com/2012/10/3-strikes|accessdate=April 24, 2017|work=For The Curious|date=October 24, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1316/is_n9_v26/ai_15856830/ |title=The right three strikes – three strikes and out law |last1=Franklin |first1=Daniel |date=September 1994 |work=Washington Monthly |accessdate=September 6, 2010}}</ref>
==Media==
[[Investigation Discovery]] re-enacted the kidnapping and murder in ''Motives & Murder: Cracking the Case: Who Took Polly Klaas?'' (Season 3 Episode 2, 2014).<ref>{{cite web|title=Cracking the Case:I Couldn't Keep Images Of Polly Klaas Out Of My Head {{!}} Investigation Discovery|url=https://www.investigationdiscovery.com/tv-shows/motives-murders-cracking-the-case/videos/cracking-the-case-i-couldnt-keep-images-of-polly-klaas-out-of-my-head|website=www.investigationdiscovery.com|accessdate=April 24, 2017|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>http://www.thewhig.com/2016/01/08/kingston-girl-hooked-on-acting</ref><!-- VOD at http://www.walmart.com/ip/40718101 -->
The [[A&E (TV network)|A&E]] television series ''[[American Justice]]'' released the episode "Free to Kill -- The Polly Klaas Murder". The episode exposes the challenges of the penal system to rehabilitate inmates. Davis had been in and out of jail, his convictions ranging from kidnapping to burglary. The episode originally aired October 23, 1996.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Justice {{!}} Season 5, Episode 26 Free to Kill: The Polly Klaas Murder|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/american-justice/episode-26-season-5/free-to-kill-the-polly-klaas-murder/194507/|website=TVGuide.com|accessdate=April 24, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=American Justice: Free to Kill - The Polly Klaas Murder - {{!}} Overview All Movie|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/american-justice-free-to-kill-the-polly-klaas-murder-v245508#MYwO1yML6tFp1MKH.99|website=AllMovie|accessdate=April 24, 2017}}</ref>
The [[Discovery Channel]] crime series ''[[The FBI Files]]''' [[List of The FBI Files episodes#Season 1 .281998.E2.80.9399.29|first episode's]] topic was the Polly Klaas case. The episode reveals the details of the FBI agents' collection of evidence and their hunt for the criminal, and originally aired October 20, 1998.<ref>{{tv.com episode|the-fbi-files/polly-klaas-kidnapped-253024|Polly Klaas: Kidnapped}}</ref><ref>{{imdb episode|0574731|Polly Klaas: Kidnapped}}</ref><ref name="FilmRise">{{cite web|title=FilmRise THE FBI FILES – Season 1 Ep 1 "Polly Klaas: Kidnapped"|url=http://filmrise.com/the-fbi-files-season-1-ep-1-polly-klaas-kidnapped/|website=filmrise.com|publisher=[[FilmRise]]|accessdate=April 24, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Polly Klaas|url=https://wn.com/polly_klaas|website=[[World News Network]]|accessdate=April 24, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
