{{Infobox monarch | image = | name = Ssekabaka Namuggala Kagali | title =[[Kabaka of Buganda]] | reign =1741 - 1750 | coronation = | predecessor =[[Mwanga I of Buganda]] | successor =[[Kyabaggu of Buganda]] | spouse =1. Nabakyaala Basuuta
2. Lady Najjuka
3. Lady Nakangu
4. Lady Nalubowa
5. Lady Nalunga
6. Lady Nawaguma | royal house = | father =Prince Musanje Golooba | mother =Namasole Nabulya Naluggwa | birth_date = | birth_place =[[Uganda]] | death_date =1750 | death_place =Nalubugo Hill | place of burial=Muyomba, Busiro |}} '''Namuggala Kagali''' was [[Kabaka of Buganda|Kabaka]] of the [[Buganda|Kingdom of Buganda]], between 1741 and 1750. He was the twenty-fourth (24th) Kabaka of Buganda. ==Claim to the throne== He was the second son of [[Prince Musanje Golooba]]. His mother was Nabulya Naluggwa of the Ndiga clan, the second of his father's [[wives]]. He [[Enthronement|ascended]] to the throne upon the death of his elder brother, [[Mwanga I of Buganda|Kabaka Mwanga I Sebanakitta]], in 1741. He established his [[Capital (political)|capital]] at [[Nansana]].{{cite web|accessdate=5 October 2014| url=http://www.royalark.net/Uganda/buganda3.htm|title=The Life And History of Kabaka Namuggala|publisher=Royalark.net}} ==Married life== He is recorded to have married six (6) wives: * Naabakyaala Basuuta, the Kaddulubaale, daughter Masembe, of the Nsenene clan * Najjuka, daughter of Gunju, of the Butiko clan * Nakangu, daughter of Kagenda, of the Mamba clan * Nalubowa, daughter of Seggiriinya, of the Ngo (Leopard) clan. * Nalunga, daughter of Terwewalwa, of the Nvuma clan. * Nawaguma, daughter of Kisuule, of the Tembo? clan ==Issue== He is recorded to have fathered three sons: * Prince (Omulangira) Kateregga, whose mother was Basuuta * Prince (Omulangira) Ngabo, whose mother was Najjuka * Prince (Omulangira) Kiboli, whose mother was Nawaguma ==The final years== Kabaka Namuggala [[abdicated]] in favor of his younger brother, [[Kyabaggu of Buganda|Kyabaggu Kabinuli]], around 1750. He died, following an accidental fall on Nalubugo Hill, after his [[abdication]].{{cite web|accessdate=5 October 2014| url=http://www.royalark.net/Uganda/buganda3.htm|title=Ssekabaka Namuggala Fell To His Death at Nalubugo Hill|publisher=Royalark.net}} He was buried at Muyomba, Busiro.{{cite web| url=http://www.buganda.com/kings.htm|title=Kabaka Namuggala Is Buried At Muyomba, Busiro|publisher=Buganda.com|accessdate=5 October 2014}} ==Succession table== {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=[[King of Buganda]]|before=[[Mwanga I of Buganda|Mwanga I Sebanakitta]]|after=[[Kyabaggu of Buganda|Kyabaggu Kabinuli]]|years=c.1741-c.1750}} {{s-end}} ==See also== * [[Kabaka of Buganda]] * [[Nansana]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.royalark.net/Uganda/buganda3.htm Genealogy of the Kabakas of Buganda] *[http://www.buganda.com/kings.htm List of the Kings of Buganda] {{DEFAULTSORT:Namuggala Of Buganda}} [[Category:Buganda]] [[Category:18th-century monarchs in Africa]] [[Category:Deaths from falls]]

{{Infobox software | name = Noble Ape | logo = Noble Ape.png | screenshot = <!-- [[File: ]] --> | caption = | collapsible = | author = [[Tom Barbalet]] | developer = | released = {{start date|1996||}} | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | programming language = [[C (programming language)]], [[Objective-C]], [[Java (programming language)]] | operating system = | platform = [[Mac OS]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Linux]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[iOS]] | size = | language = [[English language]] | status = | genre = [[simulation]], [[god game]] | license = | website = http://www.nobleape.com/ }} '''Noble Ape''' is an [[artificial life]] development project launched in June, 1996 by [[Tom Barbalet]]. It was designed to be a forum for a diversity of contributors to work towards a coherent [[cognitive]] [[simulation]] development environment.<ref name="FIRST">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Noble Ape History | url=http://www.nobleape.com/docs/acts.html | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
==The Simulation== The central software of the project is the [http://www.nobleape.com/sim/ Noble Ape Simulation], based on the ideas outlined in [http://www.nobleape.com/man/philosophic.html Noble Ape Philosophic]. There are two primary aims of the Simulation; * to simulate the biological environment the Noble Apes inhabit, and, * to simulate the Noble Apes' [[cognitive]] processes.<ref name="SECOND">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Noble Ape Simulation | url=http://www.nobleape.com/sim/ | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
The Noble Apes move around and react to external and internal events (weather, fear, panic, sleep, ...). Noble Ape integrates many concepts in the areas of [[philosophy]], [[biology]] and [[physics]].<ref name="THIRD">{{cite web | last = Cooper | first = Quentin | title = Material World BBC4 | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/thematerialworld_20030327.shtml | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
==Technology== Noble Ape is available as [[open source software]], under the [http://www.nobleape.com/man/legal.html Noble Ape Open Source License], and is distributed with Apple Computer's [[Apple Developer Tools#CHUD Tools|CHUD Tools]], included with every new [[Apple Macintosh]] computer and is used by [[Intel]].<ref name="FOURTH">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Apple's CHUD Tools, Intel and Noble Ape | url = http://www.nobleape.com/docs/on_apple.html | accessdate = 2012-02-25}}</ref> It runs under Mac, [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], and [[Unix]] platforms.<ref name="FIFTH">{{cite web | last = Slingerland | first = Nathan | title = Optimizing with Shark: Big Payoff, Small Effort | url=https://developer.apple.com/tools/shark_optimize.html | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
The graphics engine in the Noble Ape Simulation, codenamed Ocelot, is a non-[[polygonal]] engine, which allows smooth and quick rendering of land and water surfaces.<ref name="SIXTH">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Graphics in the Noble Ape Simulation | url=http://www.nobleape.com/docs/sim_graph.html | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
The Noble Ape Simulation also contains the [[programming language]], [[ApeScript]].<ref name="SEVENTH">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Introduction to ApeScript | url=http://www.nobleape.com/man/apescript_intro.html | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
Noble Ape also features a [[podcast]], [http://www.nobleape.com/reality/ Ape Reality], where various aspects of the programming, biology, philosophy and meta-theory behind the development are discussed.<ref name="EIGHT">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Ape Reality | url=http://www.nobleape.com/reality/ | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref><ref name="NINETH">{{cite web | last = Walch | first = Rob | title = Podcast411 Interview with Tom Barbalet of Ape Reality | url=http://podcast411.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=1352 | accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
==Music==
Noble Ape received a grant from the [[Australian Film Commission]] in 1998. Barbalet used this money to buy computer hardware and record an audio CD/CDROM, ''Isle of the Apes''. Having returned from the US at the end of 1998, Barbalet recorded the second CD/CDROM, ''Mind Monkeys and Purrfect Beats'' (sic). A collection of tracks from these CDs were released on the 2018 digital compilation ''Noble Ape: Project Music''. In mid-2018, Barbalet released the single ''June 13 (This is Noble Ape)'' to address some of the challenges the development has experienced over twenty two years.<ref name="TENTH">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = This is Noble Ape (Youtube) | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pJKgyfwONXI | accessdate = 2018-06-24 }}</ref>
==Video Project==
To celebrate twenty-two years of continuous development, Barbalet undertook an at-least a video per day [[vlog]] project documenting many different aspects of Noble Ape that had not been previously talked about. Barbalet noted that the reason to do this on [[YouTube]] and [[Instagram]] was to introduce a new audience to his work.<ref name="ELEVENTH">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Tom Barbalet's YouTube Channel | url=https://www.youtube.com/barbalet/ | accessdate = 2018-04-02 }}</ref>
==Sub-Projects==
Noble Ape provided the core of six different sub-projects that had been developed by Barbalet and others through the Noble Ape development history. These six sub-projects are actively maintained under the Noble Ape development.<ref name="TWELTH">{{cite web | last = Barbalet | first = Tom | title = Tom Barbalet's Github Page | url=https://www.github.com/barbalet/ | accessdate = 2018-04-02 }}</ref>
===Noble Warfare===
Noble Warfare was developed by Barbalet in [[Wilmslow]] in Cheshire. Inspired by [[Lindow Man]], Barbalet reflected on the impact unwritten wars had through history on a local population. He was also inspired by the [[Total War (series)]] of video games. Noble Warfare pits two armies defined through an [[ApeScript]]-like interface and shows how the resolution of the battles can be covered by many different probabilistic outcomes.
===Mushroom Boy===
The early development of the Mushroom Boy came from Barbalet's time in [[Canberra]], Australia. The simulation is based in a vast [[suburb]]-based landscape and uses a number of core technologies in Noble Ape to create the environment and the entities that wander through the suburban environment. The name comes from an urban terrorism simulation Barbalet initially developed with the sub-project.
===Planet Noble Ape===
Planet Noble Ape was initially developed by Barbalet in [[Sunnyvale]], California. It provides the Noble Ape Simulation as part of a planetary simulation.
===Ecosim===
Ecosim takes the ideas of the Noble Ape Simulation and creates an educational tool specifically developed to highlight concepts in biodiversity. It was developed by Barbalet in 1997-1998 based on correspondence with a high school science teacher in Australia who wanted to have a tool to teach biodiversity based on Barbalet's work with Noble Ape.
===Noble Ape Skeleton===
This sub-project comes from the work of Bob Mottram to create a [[skeleton]] and [[vascular]] simulation based on the Noble Ape Simulation. The sub-project is based on taking Mottram's work and re-integrating it with the ongoing development.
===Noble Insect===
Noble Insect came from Barbalet's time in [[Las Vegas]], Nevada. It is based on taking an [[insect brain]] and simulating that interaction with ideas and concepts developed through Noble Ape.

'''PNS ''Ghazi''''' (previously '''USS ''Diablo'' (SS-479)'''; [[reporting name]]: '''''Ghazi'''''), {{small|[[Sitara-e-Jurat|SJ]]}}, was a {{sclass-|Tench|submarine|0}} [[Diesel-electric submarine|diesel-electric]] and the first [[Fast attack Submarine|fast-attack]] submarine of the [[Pakistan Navy]], leased from the United States in 1963.<ref name="Lancer Publications, Karim">{{cite book|last1=Karim|first1=Afsir|title=Indo-Pak Relations: Viewpoints, 1989–1996|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9781897829233|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ltOgS1FjiR4C&pg=PA68&dq=pns+ghazi+leased&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjapLmmpLPQAhUCs1QKHYkNBAUQuwUIIzAB#v=onepage&q=pns%20ghazi%20leased&f=false|accessdate=18 November 2016|language=en|format=google books|chapter=The Early Years}}</ref>{{rp|68}}
She served in the [[United States Navy]] from [[History of the United States Navy|1945 to 1963]] and was loaned to Pakistan under the [[Security Assistance Program]] (SAP) on a four-year lease after the [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)|Ayub administration]] successfully negotiated with the [[Kennedy administration]] for its procurement.<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Hiranandani">{{cite book|last1=Hiranandani|first1=G. M.|title=Transition to Triumph: History of the Indian Navy, 1965–1975|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9781897829721|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zFyMKROi46kC&pg=PA108&dq=pns+ghazi+leased&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjapLmmpLPQAhUCs1QKHYkNBAUQuwUIHjAA#v=onepage&q=pns%20ghazi%20leased&f=false|accessdate=18 November 2016|language=en|format=google books|chapter=Pakistan Navy's Submarine Program}}</ref> In 1964, she joined the Pakistan Navy and saw the [[military action]]s in the [[Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts|Indo-Pakistani theaters]] in [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|1965]] and, later in [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|1971]].<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
In 1968, ''Ghazi'' executed a [[Submarine#Submersion and trimming|submerged]] [[circumnavigation]] of Africa and [[Southern Europe|southern parts]] of Europe through the [[Indian Ocean]] to the [[Atlantic Ocean]] due to the [[Six-Day War|closure of the]] [[Suez Canal]] in order to be [[refit]]ted and [[Mid-life update|update]]d at [[Gölcük Naval Shipyard|Gölcük]], Turkey. The submarine could be armed with up to ~28 [[Mark 14 torpedo|Mk.14]] torpedoes and had the capability of [[naval mine|mine-laying]] added as part of her refit.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii">{{cite web|last1=wwiiafterwwii|title=Last voyage of PNS Ghazi 1971|url=https://wwiiafterwwii.wordpress.com/2015/12/24/last-voyage-of-pns-ghazi-1971/|website=wwiiafterwwii|publisher=wwiiafterwwii|accessdate=18 November 2016|date=24 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119064646/https://wwiiafterwwii.wordpress.com/2015/12/24/last-voyage-of-pns-ghazi-1971/|archive-date=2016-11-19|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref name="defencejournal.com" />
Starting from being the only submarine in the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965]], ''Ghazi'' remained the Pakistan Navy's [[flagship]] submarine until she sank under mysterious circumstances near India's [[Bay of Bengal|eastern coast]] while conducting [[Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971|naval operations]] en route to the Bay of Bengal.<ref>{{cite book|last=Till|first=Geoffrey |title=Seapower: a guide for the twenty-first century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZcejlMRYNAAC&pg=PA179|accessdate=2010-05-28|year=2004|publisher=Frank Cast Publishers|location=Great Britain|isbn=0-7146-8436-8|page=179}}</ref> While the [[Indian Navy]] credits ''Ghazi''{{'}}s sinking to its [[destroyer]] {{INS|Rajput|D141|6}},<ref name="orb">{{cite web Indian historians consider the sinking of ''Ghazi'' to be a notable event. They have described the sinking as one of the "last unsolved greatest mysteries of the 1971 war."<ref name="India Today, 2003"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://thereel.scroll.in/827797/what-happened-on-board-the-pakistani-submarine-that-inspired-the-movie-the-ghazi-attack|title=What happened to the Pakistani submarine that inspired the movie ‘The Ghazi Attack’?|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170127185306/https://thereel.scroll.in/827797/what-happened-on-board-the-pakistani-submarine-that-inspired-the-movie-the-ghazi-attack|archive-date=2017-01-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Service with United States Navy==
{{USS|Diablo|SS-479|2}}, a long-range [[Fast attack submarine|fast-attack]] {{sclass-|Tench|submarine}} was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 1 December 1944, sponsored by the wife of U.S. Navy's [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] V. D. Chapline on 31 March 1945 with [[Lieutenant commander (United States)|Lieutenant Commander]] Gordon Graham Matheson as her first [[commanding officer]].<ref name="Hull Number">{{cite web|last1=et.al|title=USS DIABLO (SS-479) Deployments & History|url=http://www.hullnumber.com/SS-479|website=www.hullnumber.com|publisher=Hull Number|accessdate=20 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120151749/http://www.hullnumber.com/SS-479|archive-date=2016-11-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref name="uboat.net">{{cite web|title=Diablo (SS-479) of the US Navy - American Submarine of the Tench class - Allied Warships of WWII - uboat.net|url=http://uboat.net/allies/warships/ship/5903.html|website=uboat.net|publisher=uboat.net|accessdate=20 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820005813/http://www.uboat.net/allies/warships/ship/5903.html|archive-date=2010-08-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref name="TogetherWeServed -">{{cite web|title=TogetherWeServed – Connecting US Navy Sailors|url=https://navy.togetherweserved.com/usn/servlet/tws.webapp.WebApp?cmd=PublicUnitProfile&type=Unit&ID=3907|website=navy.togetherweserved.com|publisher=TogetherWeServed -|accessdate=20 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120215018/https://navy.togetherweserved.com/usn/servlet/tws.webapp.WebApp?cmd=PublicUnitProfile&type=Unit&ID=3907|archive-date=2016-11-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref name="USS Diablo SS-497" />
She was the only warship of the United States Navy to be named [[Devil|''Diablo'']], which means "devil" in [[Spanish language|Spanish]].{{rp|134–135}}<ref name="Northern Book Centre, Sagar">{{cite book|last1=Sagar|first1=Krishna Chandra|title=The War of the Twins|publisher=Northern Book Centre|isbn=9788172110826|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XM5oZYYvEmYC&pg=PA135&dq=PNS+Ghazi+Devil&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKx8rDrrfQAhWEy7wKHUTgC8sQuwUIIDAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=20 November 2016|language=en|format=google books|chapter=The Devil can't be the Defender of the Faith}}</ref> The submarine's assigned and issued [[Embroidered patch|insignia patch]] identified the [[caricature]] image of the devil running with a torpedo in the sea.<ref name="Submarine Photo Index">{{cite web|last1=Smolinski|first1=Mike|title=Patches of USS Diablo at the Submarine Photo Index|url=http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08479.htm|website=www.navsource.org|publisher=Submarine Photo Index|accessdate=20 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109100300/http://www.navsource.org/archives/08/08479.htm|archive-date=2016-11-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
As her [[keel]] was [[Keel laying|laid]] down by the [[Portsmouth Navy Yard]], ''Diablo'' arrived at [[Pearl Harbor]] from [[New London, Connecticut|New London]], [[Connecticut]] on 21 July 1945 and sailed for her first war patrol on 10 August with instructions to stop at [[Saipan]] for final orders.<ref name="USS Diablo SS-497">{{cite web|title=USS Diablo SS-497|url=http://www.historycentral.com/navy/Submarine/Diablo.html|website=www.historycentral.com|publisher=USS Diablo SS-497|accessdate=20 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120220028/http://www.historycentral.com/navy/Submarine/Diablo.html|archive-date=2016-11-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> With the [[End of World War II in Asia|ceasefire]], her destination was changed to [[Guam]] where she arrived on 22 August 1945.<ref name="FriedmanSubs1-dates" /> On the last day of the month, she got underway for Pearl Harbor and the [[United States East Coast|East Coast]] arriving at [[New York City]] on 11 October, except for a visit to [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]], [[South Carolina]] in October where she remained at New York until 8 January 1946.<ref name="TogetherWeServed -" />
From 15 January 1946 to 27 April 1949, ''Diablo'' was based in the [[Panama Canal Zone]] participating in [[Naval exercise|fleet exercises]] and rendering services to surface units in the [[Caribbean Sea]].<ref name="Register" /> From 23 August to 2 October 1947, she joined the submarines {{USS|Cutlass|SS-478|2}} and {{USS|Conger|SS-477|2}} for a simulated war patrol down the west coast of South America and around [[Tierra del Fuego]].<ref name="FriedmanSubs1-specs" /> The three submarines called at [[Valparaíso]], Chile, in September while homeward bound. ''Diablo'' sailed to [[Key West, Florida|Key West]], [[Florida]], for [[antisubmarine warfare]] exercises, from 16 November to 9 December 1947, and operated from [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], for the training of naval reservists in March 1948.<ref name="FriedmanSubs1-specs" />
''Diablo'' arrived at [[Naval Station Norfolk]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia|Virginia]], her new home port, on 5 June 1949, and participated in Operation Convex in 1951, and alternated training cruises with duty at the Sonar School at Key West.<ref name="FriedmanSubs1-dates" /> Her homeport became New London in 1952 and she arrived there 17 September to provide training facilities for the Submarine School.<ref name="Hull Number"/>
From 3 May to 1 June 1954, she was attached to the Operational Development Force at Key West for tests of new weapons and equipment.<ref name="Hull Number"/> She participated in Operation Springboard in the Caribbean from 21 February to 28 March 1955, and continued to alternate service with the Submarine School with antisubmarine warfare and fleet exercises in the Caribbean and off [[Bermuda]], as well as rendering services to the Fleet Sonar School and Operational Development Force at Key West.<ref name="TogetherWeServed -" /> Between February and April 1959, she cruised through the [[Panama Canal]] along the coasts of Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Chile for exercises with South American navies.<ref name="Hull Number"/> On 27 May 1960, she entered [[Philadelphia Naval Shipyard]] for an overhaul which continued through October 1960.<ref name="USS Diablo SS-497" />
In 1962, her [[hull classification symbol]] was changed to '''AGSS-479'''.<ref name="Register" />
==Service with Pakistan Navy== {{Main|Greater Underwater Propulsion Power Program|Pakistan–United States military relations}} [[File:USS Diablo (SS-479) in Cape Cod Canal.jpg|thumb|left|USS ''Diablo''{{'}}s [[sea trial]] in the [[Cape Cod Canal]] in 1944 ]]
The procurement and acquisition of ''Ghazi'' was a result of lengthy and complicated negotiation between the administrations of [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan]] and the [[Federal government of the United States|United States]].{{rp|57–60}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Goldrick">{{cite book|last1=Goldrick|first1=James|title=No Easy Answers: The Development of the Navies of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka, 1945–1996|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9781897829028|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6XW7kKHQeQoC&pg=PA83&dq=ghazi+no+easy+answer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKgv211rPQAhVLjFQKHegwCkwQ6wEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=ghazi&f=false|accessdate=19 November 2016|language=en}}</ref> Since the 1950s the Pakistan Navy had been seeking to procure imported submarines, initially negotiating with the [[Royal Navy]] and subsequently also with the United States Navy.{{rp|58}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Goldrick"/>
With [[President Ayub Khan|Ayub administration]] improving relations with the [[Eisenhower Administration|Eisenhower administration]] in 1960, ''Ghazi'' was finally procured under the [[Security Assistance Program]] (SAP) authorised by the [[Kennedy administration]] on a four-year lease with an option of renewing or purchasing the submarine afterwards in 1963.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /><ref name="defencejournal.com">{{cite web|last1=Tasnim|first1=Vice-Admiral Ahmed|title=Remembering Our Warriors – Vice Admiral Tasneem|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2001/may/tasneem.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=Vice Admiral A. Tasnim, Defence Journal|accessdate=17 November 2016|language=Eng|date=May 2001|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510114649/http://www.defencejournal.com/2001/may/tasneem.htm|archive-date=2017-05-10|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
''Ghazi'' was the first submarine to be operated by a Navy in [[South Asia]] becoming a serious threat to the Indian Navy.<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Goldrick"/><ref name="Routledge, Dittmer">{{cite book|last1=Dittmer|first1=Lowell|title=South Asia's Nuclear Security Dilemma: India, Pakistan, and China: India, Pakistan, and China|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317459552|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X2PxBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT105&dq=ghazi+first+submarine&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiR06-63LPQAhUIsFQKHcIuB2cQuwUILzAD#v=onepage&q=ghazi%20first%20submarine&f=false|accessdate=19 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>{{rp|60}} Contrary to popular perception, ''Ghazi'' technological feats were downgraded and extensively refitted its [[Fleet Snorkel]] under the [[Greater Underwater Propulsion Power Program|Guppy program]] of the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] at the [[Philadelphia Naval Shipyard|Philadelphia Naval Dockyard]], and was mostly unmodernized when she joined the services of Pakistan Navy.{{rp|61}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Goldrick"/> Naval historians had described ''Ghazi'' as an unarmed "clockwork mouse" used for training purposes.{{rp|61}}<ref name="Northern Book Centre, Sagar"/><ref name="Lancer Publishers, Goldrick"/>{{rp|135–136}} Nonetheless, the Indian Navy immediately was under the impression that it was militarized and an updated submarine that posed a serious threat.{{rp|59}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Goldrick"/>
She was fitted with 14 vintage [[Mark 14 torpedo|Mark-14]] torpedoes which had the [[Mark 14 torpedo#Problems|controversy and notoriety]] of its own during the [[World War II]].<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> On 4 September 1964, she arrived at the [[Karachi Naval Dockyard|Naval Dockyard]] in [[Karachi]] and joined the Navy as its first-ever long-range [[Fast attack Submarine|fast-attack]] submarine.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium">{{cite web|last1=Usman|first1=Tariq|title=The Ghazi That Defied The Indian Navy «|url=http://pakdef.org/the-ghazi-that-defied-the-indian-navy/|website=pakdef.org|publisher=PakDef Military Consortium|accessdate=19 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308223346/http://pakdef.org/the-ghazi-that-defied-the-indian-navy/|archivedate=8 March 2017|df=}}</ref> She was named and designated as ''Ghazi'' (lit. Holiest Warrior) by the Pakistan Navy in 1964.{{rp|136}}<ref name="Northern Book Centre, Sagar"/>
===Western Front of the Indo-Pakistani war of 1965=== {{Main|Indo-Pakistani War of 1965#Naval hostilities|l1=Naval operations in the 1965 Indo-Pakistani war theatre}} [[File:Admiral.K.R.Niazi.jpg|thumb|right|Combat control center of ''Ghazi'' as [[periscope]] held by [[Commander (rank)|Cdr]] [[Karamat Rahman Niazi|K.R. Niazi]] in 1965]] On 5 August 1965, the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|war]] broke out between [[India and Pakistan]] as a result of [[Operation Gibraltar|covert infiltration]] in [[Indian-held Kashmir|Indian Kashmir]], and ''Ghazi'', at that time, was under the command of then-[[Commander (naval)|Commander]] [[Karamat Rahman Niazi]], who would later ascend as a [[Four star admiral|four-star]] admiral in the Navy.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> Other officers who served in ''Ghazi'' were then-[[Lieutenant-Commander]] [[Ahmed Tasnim]] (later promoted as [[Vice admiral|Vice-Admiral]]), [[Sub-lieutenant|Sub-Lieutenant]] [[Fasih Bokhari]], and [[Lieutenant (naval)|Lieutenant]] [[Zafar Muhammad Khan|Zafar Muhammad]] who would later command her, as a Commander, in 1971.<ref name="Roli Books Private Limited">{{cite book|last1=Cardozo|first1=Major General Ian|title=The Sinking of INS Khukri: Survivor's Stories|publisher=Roli Books Private Limited|isbn=9789351940999|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xvs_CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT28&lpg=PT28&dq=Ahmed+Tasnim+ghazi&source=bl&ots=eyfxZuMVjh&sig=RvIz3Hhh-AET1eNoAtqywBltHCg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiD45b04LPQAhVmilQKHQQVBokQ6AEIQDAG#v=onepage&q=Ahmed%20Tasnim%20ghazi&f=false|accessdate=19 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
The notable [[commanding officer]]s of ''Ghazi'' in [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|1965]] included: **[[Commander (rank)|Cdr.]] [[Karamat Rahman Niazi|K.R. Nyazi]]– [[Officer in Charge|Ofc–in–chrg.]]{{disambiguation needed|date=September 2018}} of ''Ghazi''. **[[Lieutenant-Commander|Lt-Cdr.]] [[Ahmed Tasnim]]–[[Second-in-command|2nd-in-Cmd.]] of ''Ghazi'' **[[Lieutenant (naval)|Lt.]] [[Zafar Muhammad Khan|Z.M. Khan]]– Chief [[Navigation officer]] in ''Ghazi'' **[[Sub-lieutenant|S-Lt.]] [[Fasih Bokhari]]–then [[Mark 14 torpedo|Torpedo officer]] in ''Ghazi'' **[[Chief Petty Officer|CPO]] Lal Khan Satti– chief [[quartermaster]]. She was the only submarine in the conflict arena that was deployed in the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|war theatre]] with a mission scope of attacking only heavy and major warships of the Indian Navy.<ref name="Roy1995">{{cite book|last=Roy|first=Mihir K.|title=War in the Indian Ocean|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tqr8r7EB18wC&pg=PA118|accessdate=8 November 2011|year=1995|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=978-1-897829-11-0|pages=83–85}}</ref> She only aided the flotilla under the command of [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] S.M. Anwar that launched a [[Operation Dwarka|naval attack]] on radar station in [[Dwarka]], [[Gujarat, India|Gujarat]], India.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> In addition, she was also seeking {{INS|Vikrant|R11|6}}, the only [[aircraft carrier]], but did not detect her target during the entire conflict.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> On 9 September 1965, [[Leopard-class frigate|INS ''Beas'']] made an unsuccessful [[depth charge]] attack in an attempt to make a contact with ''Ghazi''.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
On 17 September 1965, ''Ghazi'' made a surface contact and identified [[Leopard-class frigate|INS ''Brahmaputra'']] and fired three [[World War II]]-origin Mark 14 torpedoes and increased depth to evade the counterattack.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> According to submarine [[War diary|war logs]], there were three distinct [[explosion]]s that were heard at about the time when the torpedoes should have impacted but ''Brahmaputra'' was not sunk neither it had been hit it since the warship did not released the depth charge nor it had detected the [[Homing missile|homing signal]].<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> No ships were sunk or damaged in the area and ''Ghazi'' safely reported back to base.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
Upon her return, she won ten war awards including two decorations of ''[[Sitara-e-Jurat]]'', one ''[[Tamgha-i-Jurat]]'', and the [[Pride of Performance|President's citations]] and six [[Imtiazi Sanad]]s while her commander, Cdr. K.R. Niazi was decorated with the Sitara-e-Jurat and [[chief petty officer]]s were decorated with the Tamgha-i-Jurat.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /><ref name="Roli Books Private Limited"/> It is not known what ''Ghazi''{{'}}s target was or what were the three mysterious explosions were since no inquiry report was ever submitted.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
After the war, an arms embargo was placed in 1965–66 on both India and Pakistan but was later waived by the United States that was strictly based on the [[Cash and carry (wholesale)|cash and carry]] method as ''Ghazi'' badly needing refitting.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> In 1967, the Navy applied to renew another four-year lease deal which was duly approved by the U.S. Navy and the U.S. Government but her material state and equipment continued to deteriorate.{{rp|108}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Hiranandani"/> The Navy then signed a deal with the [[Turkish Navy]] for a [[refit]] and [[mid-life update]] that was to be carried out at Gölcük in Turkey – the only facility to update the ''Tench''-class submarines.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
Because of the [[Six-Day War]] in [[Middle East]] which had closed the [[Suez Canal]] due to the [[Egyptian Navy]]'s [[Naval blockade|blockage]] in 1967, ''Ghazi'', under the command of Commander [[Ahmed Tasnim]], had to execute a submerged [[circumnavigation]] in 1968 from Africa to [[Western Europe]] which began from [[Karachi coast]] to [[Cape of Good Hope]], South Africa and then through the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and it ended at the east coast of the [[Sea of Marmara]] where the [[Gölcük Naval Shipyard]] is located.{{rp|108}}<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /><ref name="Lancer Publishers, Hiranandani"/><ref name="defencejournal.com"/> [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff]] Admiral [[Syed Mohammad Ahsan|S.M. Ahsan]] had arranged necessary refitting of ''Ghazi''{{'}}s [[computer]]s at the [[Karachi Shipyard|Karachi Engineering and Shipyard Works]] (KESW) from the help from the local industry such as [[DESTO (Pakistan)|DESTO]].<ref name="defencejournal.com"/>
During her submerged circumnavigation voyage, she briefly stopped at [[Mombasa]], Kenya for refueling and, in [[Maputo]], Mozambique before making a farewell visit at [[Simon's Town]], South Africa.<ref name="defencejournal.com"/> After passing the [[Cape of Good Hope]], she made another stopover at [[Luanda]], Angola for victualing and continued her journey towards Western Europe to stopover at [[Toulon]], France where she was greeted by the [[French Navy]].<ref name="defencejournal.com"/> Her final stopover was at [[İzmir]] in Turkey and submerged through the east coast of the Sea of Marmara to dock at the Gölcük Naval Shipyard which was the only facility to upgrade the ''Tench''-class based computers and other [[Electromechanical Engineering|electromechanical]] equipments.<ref name="defencejournal.com"/> It took her two months to complete her circumnavigation of Africa and Europe.<ref name="defencejournal.com"/>
The deal for refitting and [[Mid-life update|mid-life]] upgrading of her [[military computer]]s reportedly cost ~[[United States Dollar|$]]1.5 million ([[US$|$]]11.1 million in [[Fiscal year|2015–16]]).<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> The program started in March 1968 and completed in April 1970 and it is believed that the U.S-made ill-fitted World War II era Mk.14/[[Mark 10 torpedo|Mk.10]] [[naval mine]]s were bought "[[Corruption in Turkey|secretly]]" from Turkey.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
===Eastern Front of Indo-Pakistani war of 1971=== {{Main|Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971#Naval operations in the Eastern theatre|l1=Naval operations in the Eastern theatre}}
Under the command of Lieutenant Commander Yousaf Raza, ''Ghazi'' returned to [[Karachi coast]] after successfully completing the submerged circumnavigation of Africa which was taken in order to undergo a refitting program and mid-life updates of her military computers on 2 April 1970.{{rp|108}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Hiranandani" /><ref name="defencejournal.com" />
In August 1971, the Indian Navy transferred INS ''Vikrant'', its aircraft carrier, to the [[Eastern Naval Command]] in [[Visakhapatnam]] that forced the Pakistan Navy to adjust its submarine operations.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> Before 1971, there were several proposals made to the Ayub administration to strengthen the naval defense of [[East Pakistan]] but none were made feasible and the Navy was in no position to mount a defence against an approaching Indian naval advances.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> After the [[Operation Jackpot|defection]] of officers and sailors of [[Bangladesh Navy|East-Pakistan Navy]] to India, the [[Pakistan Eastern Command|Eastern Command]] was under intense pressure to counter the insurgency and the advance of the Indian Army towards East Pakistan on three fronts.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> The [[Yahya Khan|Yahya administration]] insisted the Navy attempt to reinforce the naval defence of the East while the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] objected to the idea of deploying ''Ghazi'' in the total absence of a seaport, straying away from their original plan.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> Many senior commanders had felt that the deployment of ''Ghazi'' was highly dangerous and impossible to achieve by sending the obsolete submarine behind enemy lines but deployment came when it became apparent that the war was inevitable.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" />
Prior to her deployment, ''Ghazi'' continued to experience equipment failures and reportedly had aging issues. Since it was the only submarine of the Pakistan Navy and had the range and capability to undertake operations in the distant waters controlled by India, ''Ghazi'' was pressed into operation to destroy or damage ''Vikrant''.<ref name="autogenerated179">Till, Geoffrey (2004). Seapower: a guide for the twenty-first century. Great Britain: Frank Cass Publishers. p. 179. {{ISBN|0-7146-8436-8}}. Retrieved 2010-05-28.</ref> On 14 November 1971, she quietly sailed {{convert|3,000|mi|km}} around the Indian peninsula from the [[Arabian Sea]] to the Bay of Bengal under the command of Zafar Muhammad who was commanding a submarine for the first time, with 10 officers and 82 sailors.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /><ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> ''Ghazi'' was on a two-fold mission: the primary goal was to [[Seek and destroy|locate and sink]] ''Vikrant'' and secondary was to mine India's eastern seaboard which was to be fulfilled irrespective of the accomplishment of the first.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
==Fate==
The mysterious sinking of ''Ghazi'' took place on 4 December 1971 during its hunt to find ''Vikrant'' and/or during the minelaying mission on the [[Visakhapatnam Port]], Bay of Bengal.<ref name="autogenerated179"/> The true cause of the sinking is still unknown, and Indian and Pakistani sources have different views.
On 16 November, she was in contact with the Navy NHQ and Commander Khan charted the [[Coordinate system|coordinates]] that reported that she was {{convert|400|km|mi}} off [[Bombay]].{{rp|82}}<ref name="Beacon Press, Zakaria">{{cite book|last1=Zakaria|first1=Rafia|title=The Upstairs Wife: An Intimate History of Pakistan|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=9780807080467|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C7DaCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82|accessdate=20 November 2016|language=en}}</ref> On 19 November, she was off to [[Sri Lanka]] and entered in Bay of Bengal on 20 November 1971.{{rp|82}}<ref name="Beacon Press, Zakaria"/> Around this time, the [[Top Secret]] files were opened as instructed and the hunt for ''Vikrant'' began on 23 November and ''Ghazi'' was off to [[Madras]] where reportedly the Indian aircraft carrier was stationed but she was 10 days late and ''Vikrant'' was now actually somewhere near the [[Andaman Islands]].{{rp|82}}<ref name="Beacon Press, Zakaria"/><ref>{{cite book|title=In Quest of Freedom: The War of 1971 – Personal Accounts by Soldiers from India and Bangladesh|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9789386141668|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I0r2DAAAQBAJ&pg=PT285&dq=PNS+Ghazi+vikrant+island&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiA2vPf97fQAhXGv1QKHQ4zAGMQuwUIHDAA#v=onepage&q=PNS%20Ghazi%20vikrant%20island&f=false|accessdate=20 November 2016|language=en}}</ref> Unable to detect her target, ''Ghazi''{{'}}s commanders became [[Delusional intuition|delusional]] from their hunt for ''Vikrant'' and turned back to Visakhapatnam to start laying mines off the harbour with a confidence that it will take its swipe at ''Vikrant'' or at least bottle up the Indian Navy's heavy units clustered in this major Indian naval base on the night of 2–3 December 1971."<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" />
On 1 December 1971, [[Vice Admiral]] [[Nilakanta Krishnan]] briefed Captain Inder Singh, the commanding officer of {{INS|Rajput|1942|6}}, that a Pakistani submarine had been sighted off the Sri Lankan coast and was absolutely certain that the submarine would be somewhere around Madras or Visakhapatnam.<ref name="br" /> He made it clear that once ''Rajput'' had completed refueling, she must leave the harbor with all navigational aids switched off.<ref name="br" />
According to Indian claims, at 23:40 on 3 December 1971, taking on board a pilot, ''Rajput'' moved through the channel to the exit from Visakhapatnam.<ref name="br" /><ref name="al" />
Exactly at midnight, shortly after passing the entrance buoy, the starboard lookout reported a breaker on the surface of the water right on the nose. According to the Indian Navy's claims, Captain Singh changed the course at full speed across the specified point and ordered to drop two depth charges, which was done.<ref name="br" /> The explosions were "stunning", and ''Rajput'' suffered a serious material concussion to its structure. However, visible results of this attack are not given.<ref name="br" /> ''Rajput'' for some time surveyed the area dumping bombs, no longer found any contact — either visual or acoustic. A few minutes later, the destroyer continued her way to the coast of East Pakistan.<ref name="br" /><ref name="al" />
On the night of the 4–5 December 1971, ''Ghazi'' sunk with all 93 servicemen on board (11 officers and 82 enlisted<ref>{{cite web |title=PNS/M Ghazi : Officers and Enlisted |url=http://pakdef.org/pnsm-ghazi/ |website=pakdef.org |accessdate=7 September 2018}}</ref>) under the mysterious circumstances{{rp|157}}<ref name="autogenerated179"/><ref name="Psychology Press, Till"/> off the Visakhapatnam coast, allowing the Indian Navy to effect a naval blockade of East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).{{rp|157}}<ref name="Psychology Press, Till">{{cite book|last1=Till|first1=Geoffrey|title=Seapower: A Guide for the Twenty-first Century|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=9780714655420|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vQVQ_dTVVzwC&pg=PA157&dq=pns+ghazi+lost&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiAz4W-gbjQAhXCwVQKHbdgCkYQuwUIQzAH#v=onepage&q=pns%20ghazi%20lost&f=false|accessdate=20 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
===Intelligence and deception=== {{Main|Military deception}} According to [[Directorate of Naval Intelligence (India)|Indian DNI]]'s director Rear-Admiral Mihir K. Roy, ''Ghazi''{{'}}s existence was revealed when a signal addressed to naval authorities in [[Chittagong]] was intercepted, requesting information on a lubrication oil only used by submarines and [[minesweeper]]s.<ref name="autogenerated179"/><ref name="roy">Mihir K. Roy (1995) War in the Indian Ocean, Spantech & Lancer. {{ISBN|978-1-897829-11-0}}</ref>
Indian Navy intelligence tracked ''Ghazi'' with a codename issued as ''[[Kali Devi]]'',<ref name="Defence Journal, Azam"/> and the Indian Navy began to realize that the Pakistanis would inevitably be forced to send their submarine ''Ghazi'' to the Bay of Bengal, as the sole ship which could operate in these waters.<ref name="Defence Journal, Azam">{{cite web|last1=Khan|first1=Commander Azam|title=Maritime Awareness and Pakistan Navy|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2000/mar/maritime.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=Defence Journal, Azam|accessdate=20 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309235258/http://www.defencejournal.com/2000/mar/maritime.htm|archive-date=2016-03-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
Vice Admiral [[Nilakanta Krishnan]] of the [[Eastern Naval Command]] had maintained that it was pretty clear that Pakistan would have deployed ''Ghazi'' in the Bay of Bengal and a part of its plan was an attempt to sink the Indian aircraft carrier ''Vikrant''.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> At the same time concerted action was taken to disseminate [[Misinformation effect|misinformation]] designed to mislead the enemy about the true location of the aircraft carrier, and to foster confidence that the carrier was stationed at Visakhapatnam.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /><ref name="br">{{cite web |url=http://www.bharat-rakshak.com/MONITOR/ISSUE4-2/harry.html |title=Bharat Rakshak Monitor: Volume 4(2) September–October 2001 |publisher=Bharat-rakshak.com |accessdate=2011-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128104709/http://www.bharat-rakshak.com/MONITOR/ISSUE4-2/harry.html |archivedate=2011-11-28 |df= }}</ref>
All these activities were apparently successful in deceiving ''Ghazi'' when on 25 November 1971, the Navy NHQ [[Communication with submarines|communicated]] with ''Ghazi'' that stated: "INTEL INDICATES CARRIER IN PORT Visakhapatnam".<ref name="al">{{cite web |url=http://www.almanacwhf.ru/?no=4&art=6 |title=Войны, история, факты. Альманах |publisher=Almanacwhf.ru |accessdate=2011-12-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201171113/http://www.almanacwhf.ru/?no=4&art=6 |archive-date=2012-02-01 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
==Aftermath==
On 26 November 1971, ''Ghazi'' was expected to communicate with the Navy NHQ to submit its mission report but did not communicate with its base.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi">{{cite web|last1=Shabbir|first1=Usman|title=Operations in the Bay of Bengal: The Loss of PNS/M Ghazi« PakDef Military Consortium|url=http://pakdef.org/operations-in-the-bay-of-bengal/|website=pakdef.org|publisher=Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi|accessdate=22 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220073143/http://pakdef.org/operations-in-the-bay-of-bengal/|archivedate=20 February 2017|df=}}</ref> The Navy NHQ repeatedly made frantic efforts to establish the communication and anxiety grew as days passed for her return to the base.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi"/> Before the [[Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971|naval hostilities]] broke out, commanding officers had started worrying about ''Ghazi''{{'}}s fate and had already began to agitate their minds but the Navy NHQ senior command had replied to their junior officers that several reasons could, however, be attributed to the failure of the submarine to communicate.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi"/>
On 9 December, the Indian Navy strangely issued a statement about the fate of ''Ghazi.'' The first indication of ''Ghazi''{{'}}s fate came when a message from the Indian NHQ, claiming sinking of ''Ghazi'' on the night of 3 December, was intercepted.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi"/> The Indian NHQ issued the statement a few hours before the loss of {{INS|Khukri|1958|6}}, and prior to launch of [[Operation Python|second missile attack]] on Karachi port.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi"/>
===Indian version===
After the [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|ceasefire]] in 1971, the [[Government of India]] undertook an investigation into the incident and immediately claimed that the submarine was sunk following the series of maneuvers by the Indian Navy.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi"/> A submarine rescue vessel, INS ''Karanj'' was sent to check the debris and India later built a "Victory Memorial" on the coast near where ''Ghazi'' was sunk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vizag.metromela.com/Victory+at+Sea,+a+war+memorial/article/3984|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420041733/http://vizag.metromela.com/Victory+at+Sea,+a+war+memorial/article/3984|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-04-20|title=Victory at Sea memorial at Vizag}}</ref> India credits the [[HMS Rotherham (H09)|INS ''Rajput'']] for sinking ''Ghazi'' and her crew were honored with [[Awards and Decorations of the Indian Armed Forces|gallantry awards]] for this event, but the actual details of ''Ghazi''{{'}}s sinking soon began to emerge after the war.<ref name="Register" />
The claim of sinking ''Ghazi'' has been a center of controversy between the Indian authors, giving doubts in their theories of mysterious sinking of the submarine.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi"/> With Commodore Ranjit Roy testifying that "very loud explosion effects were heard at the beach that came from underwater."<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi" /> Commodore Roy also concluded that "...at that time, how the ''Ghazi'' was sunk remained unclear as it does today."<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi" />
The official history of Indian Navy: ‘''Transition to Triumph''’, authored by retired Vice-Admiral [[Gulab Mohanlal Hiranandani|G.M. Hiranandani]], gave exhaustive account of the sinking of ''Ghazi'' and quoted that the naval records and top naval officials who commanded operations on the eastern seafront as saying that INS ''Rajput'' was sent from Visakhapatnam to track down ''Ghazi''. The book also noted that the time of dropping of the charges, the explosion which was heard by the people of Visakhapatnam and that of a clock recovered from ''Ghazi'', matched.<ref>Vice-Admiral (Retd) G M Hiranandani, ''Transition to Triumph: Indian Navy 1965–1975''. {{ISBN|1-897829-72-8}}</ref> However, Admiral Hiranandani maintained that the submarine almost certainly suffered an internal explosion but its causes are debatable.<ref name="India Today, 2003" />
Admiral Roy of India states: "The theories propounded earlier by some who were unaware of the ''[[ruse de guerre]]'' (attempt to fool the enemy in wartime) leading to the sinking of the first submarine in the Indian Ocean gave rise to smirks from within our own (Indian) naval service for an operation which instead merited a ''[[Bravo Zulu]]'' (flag hoist for Well Done)".<ref name="roy" />
Admiral [[S.M. Nanda|S. M. Nanda]], [[Chief of Naval Staff (India)|Chief of Naval Staff]] of the Indian Navy during the conflict, stated : "In narrow channels, ships, during an emergency or war, always throw depth charges around them to deter submarines. One of them probably hit the ''Ghazi''. The blow-up was there, but nobody knew what it was all about until the fisherman found the life jacket".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/jan/22inter.htm|title=The Rediff Interview/Admiral S M Nanda (retd) 'Does the US want war with India?'|last=Sengupta|first=Ramananda|date=22 January 2007|work=Interview|publisher=Rediff|accessdate=26 March 2010|location=India|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025190541/http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/jan/22inter.htm|archive-date=2010-10-25|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
In 2003, the Indian Navy again sent its divers to overlook its investigation and the divers recovered some items including the [[War diary|war logs]], officials [[Backup validation|backup]] [[VHS|tapes]] from her computers, and mission files that were displaced in [[Eastern Naval Command]] of Indian Navy, but the divers who studied the wreckage confirmed that the submarine must have suffered an internal explosion which blew up its mines and torpedoes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020721/spectrum/main2.htm |title=Naval museums give glimpse of maritime history |author=Trilochan Singh Trewn |date=July 21, 2002 |publisher=The ''Tribune'' |accessdate=May 16, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930061104/http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020721/spectrum/main2.htm |archive-date=2007-09-30 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Another theory suggests an explosion of [[hydrogen gas]] which violently built up inside the submarine while its batteries were being charged underwater.<ref name="India Today, 2003" />
In 2010, [[Lieutenant-General]] [[JFR Jacob|J.F.R Jacob]] of [[Eastern Command (India)|Eastern Command]] mentioned in an article that "''Ghazi'' was destroyed in an accident in which [[Indian Navy]] was not involved. There were many opinions from authors of the Indian side who also shared this skepticism of the Indian Navy’s official stance.<ref name="The Express Tribune, 2012 Mulki"/><ref name="The Express Tribune, 2012 Mulki">{{cite news|last1=Mulki|first1=Muhammad Abid|title=Warriors of the waves|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/383024/warriors-of-the-waves/|accessdate=23 November 2016|work=The Express Tribune|agency=The Express Tribune|publisher=The Express Tribune, 2012 Mulki|date=27 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161124024723/http://tribune.com.pk/story/383024/warriors-of-the-waves/|archive-date=2016-11-24|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> In 2011, former Indian naval chief, Admiral [[Arun Prakash]] quoted in the national security conference that [''Ghazi''] had sunk under mysterious circumstances, "not by INS Rajput as originally claimed."<ref name="News X">{{cite news|title=Ghazi sank due to internal explosion: Ex-Navy Chief|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uGztly-lEvg|accessdate=23 November 2016|agency=News X|publisher=News X|date=14 September 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160618173007/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uGztly-lEvg|archive-date=2016-06-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===Pakistani military oversights=== {{Main|High-test peroxide|Nickel–hydrogen battery|Endothermic process}} [[File:Mark 14 torpedo side view and interior mechanisms, Torpedoes Mark 14 and 23 Types, OP 635, March 24 1945.jpg|thumb|The sideview of [[Mark 14 torpedo|Mk.14]] torpedoes deployed in ''Ghazi'']] In 1972, the [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission]] (HRC) never carried out investigation into this incident despite its formation to assess the [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|military and political failures]] of the country in the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|war]] of 1971.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pppusa.org/Acrobat/Hamoodur%20Rahman%20Commission%20Report.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304011310/http://www.pppusa.org/Acrobat/Hamoodur%20Rahman%20Commission%20Report.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
It was only on 10 February 1972, when the incident was officially recognized by the [[Government of Pakistan]] and then-[[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto|Zulfikar Bhutto]] met with the [[Grief|grieving]] families and loved ones of the officers and sailors who served in ''Ghazi'', and told them that they may have all perished due to this incident as many of the slain family members were [[Transfer of Population Under the Terms of Delhi Agreement|pushing for repatriation]] to the [[Government of Pakistan]] as they were keeping the hope alive that they may have survived and rescued by India.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi" />
The [[Naval Intelligence (Pakistan)|Naval Intelligence]] conducted its own investigations and its military oversights stated that ''Ghazi'' sank, when the mines it was laying, were accidentally detonated.<ref name="Navy ISPR Investigations">{{cite web|last1=Navy ISPR|title=Pakistan Navy Official Website|url=http://www.paknavy.gov.pk/submarine_Force.html|website=www.paknavy.gov.pk|publisher=Navy ISPR Investigations|accessdate=22 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161123002402/http://www.paknavy.gov.pk/submarine_Force.html|archivedate=23 November 2016|df=}}</ref> Pakistani military oversights into this incident were not immediate instead, the Naval Intelligence took time to conclude its investigations that went on for several years.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> Over the decades, the military oversights were kept hidden and were not known to the public until [[:Category:1990s in Pakistan|1990s]] when the Navy made an announcement over the completion of its insights into this incident.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /><ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /> Following this announcement, Pakistan addressed the problems connecting the [[Mechatronics|electromechanical]] failures, computer problems, and [[Mark 14 Torpedo|Mk.14]] torpedoes' "circular deep running" once launched from the firing ship.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
Pakistan never accepted the theory from Indian Navy but provided its alternative insights into this disaster based on the investigations on the [[Mark 14 torpedo#Problems|Mark 14]] torpedoes and other vintage military equipment installed in ''Ghazi''.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /> According to Pakistan Navy's investigation, there were two probable reasons connecting to this [[Mishappenings|mishappening]]: * *''[[Magnetic pistol|Magnetic Exploder]]/[[Hydrogen explosion]]'': A [[USS Sargo (SS-188)|Sargo-type]] [[lead-acid battery]] may have over-produced the [[Hydrogen gas]] during the charging of submarine's batteries that may have led to the violent internal explosion.<ref name="Defence Journal, Azam" /> * *''Detonation of a mine inside the submarine'': This was often cited by the Pakistan Navy as the World War II-era Mk.10/Mk.14 torpedoes may have deep "circular" run, failing to straighten its run once set on its prescribed [[Gyrocompass|gyro-angle setting]], and instead, to run in a large circle, thus returning to strike the firing ship.<ref name="PakDef Military Consortium" /><ref name="Navy ISPR Investigations" /><ref>The event was visualized in telefilm, ''Ghazi Shaheed'' in 1998 during the climax of its script.</ref><ref name="Pakistan Navy">{{cite web|title=PNS Ghazi Shaheed – Last footage|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x2m5wr4|website=Dailymotion|publisher=Pakistan Navy|accessdate=23 November 2016|date=9 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161123211121/http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x2m5wr4|archive-date=2016-11-23|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
Another more plausible theory from foreign experts, also favored by Pakistan, is that the [[Explosion|explosive]] [[shock wave]]s from one of the depth charges set off the torpedoes and mines (some of which may have been armed for laying) stored aboard the submarine.<ref name="br" /><ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi" /> The [[Naval Headquarters (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] counter-argued: ''Ghazi'' itself may have inadvertently passed over the mines during the mine laying operations; patrolling Indian vessels or Indian depth charges might also have tripped the count mechanism of one or more mines.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, loss of Ghazi" /> Credibility is added to this story by the later discovery made by [[Indian Coast Guard]] divers in 2003, that the damaged parts of the submarine had been blown inside out.<ref name="br" /><ref>Transition to triumph: history of the Indian Navy, 1965–1975 By G. M. Hiranandani</ref>
In addition, the [[Naval Intelligence (Pakistan)|NI]]'s investigations also exposed the ill-considered deployment of ''Ghazi'' when it was indicated that there was no indication that ''Ghazi's'' crew had ever practiced with mines.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" />
In 2006, Pakistan, citing their evidences, vehemently rejected India's claim of sinking ''Ghazi'' and termed the claims as "false and utterly absurd".<ref name="Times of India, 2006">{{cite news|last1=Staff writer|title=India did not sink Ghazi: Pak commander – Times of India|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/India-did-not-sink-Ghazi-Pak-commander/articleshow/914230.cms|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=The Times of India|agency=Times of India|publisher=Times of India, 2006|date=24 December 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404180651/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/India-did-not-sink-Ghazi-Pak-commander/articleshow/914230.cms|archive-date=2017-04-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===Neutral witnesses and assessments===
An independent testimony stems from an [[Egyptian Navy]] officer, who claimed that the Indian ships were docked at the Visakhapatnam.<ref name=egyptianwitness>{{cite journal|last1=Johnson|first1=Ken|title=PNS Ghazi|journal=Hooter Hilites|issue=December 2007|page=6|url=http://ussseaowl.com/PDFFolder/Newsletter12-2007.pdf|accessdate=23 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304091200/http://ussseaowl.com/PDFFolder/Newsletter12-2007.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
Many independent writers and investigators maintained ''Ghazi'' was sunk mysteriously not by two depth charges alone– ''Ghazi'' may have sunk either by the hydrogen explosion produced when the batteries were charging, or by the detonation of a mine, or either by the sea floor impact while trying to avoid the depth charge released by INS ''Rajput''.<ref name="wwiiafterwwii" /><ref name="India Today, 2003" /><ref name="Defence Journal, Azam" />
In 2012, Pakistani [[Investigative journalism|investigative journalists]] from ''[[The Express Tribune]]'' who were affiliated with the [[Express News (Pakistan)|Express News USA]] based in the [[Washington D.C.]] were able to get in touch with ''Diablo's''' retired and now-aged former US Navy crew members who were allowed to study the sonar pictures and sketches of the sunken vessel where they believed that: "an explosion in the Forward Torpedo Room (FTR) destroyed the Ghazi."<ref name="The Express Tribune, 2012 Mulki" /> This view is also shared by Indian journalist Sandeep Unnithan, who specializes in military and strategic analysis.<ref name="The Express Tribune, 2012 Mulki" />
===Recovery of sunken vessel===
In 1972, both the United States and the [[Soviet Union]] offered to raise the submarine to the surface at their own expense.<ref name=roy /> The Government of India, however, rejected these offers and allowed the submarine to sink further into the mud off the fairway [[buoy]] of Visakhapatnam.<ref name=roy />
In 2003, Indian Navy [[MARCOS|divers]] recovered few items from the submarine and brought up six bloated bodies of Pakistani servicemen when they blasted their way into the submarine.<ref name="India Today, 2003" /> All six servicemen were given military honorary burial by the Indian Navy. Items recovered were the back-up tapes of the radar computers, war logs, broken [[Porthole|windshield]], top secret files, as well as one of the bodies of a [[Petty officer|Petty Officer]] [[Mechanical Engineer]] (POME) who had a wheel spanner tightly grasped in his fist.<ref name="India Today, 2003" /> Another sailor had in his pocket a [[Love letter|letter]] written in [[Urdu]] to his [[fiancée]].<ref name="India Today, 2003" />
In 2003, additional photos were released by the Indian Navy of the vessel.<ref name="India Today, 2003" />
==Legacy==
===In memory=== {{Main|PNS Ghazi (S134)}} In 1972, ''Ghazi'' and her serving officers as well as crew members were honored with [[Military awards of pakistan|gallantry awards]] by the Government of Pakistan.<ref name="pakdef.org">{{cite web|last1=Shabbir|first1=Usman|title=List of Gallantry Awardees – PN Officers/CPOs/Sailors « PakDef Military Consortium|url=http://pakdef.org/list-of-gallantry-awardees-pn-officerscpossailors/|website=pakdef.org|publisher=pakdef.org|accessdate=20 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810172213/http://pakdef.org/list-of-gallantry-awardees-pn-officerscpossailors/|archivedate=10 August 2017|df=}}</ref><ref name="Navy ISPR">{{cite web|last1=Navy ISPR|title=Untold Stories of PNS Ghazi & PNS Hangor – Video Dailymotion|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x31ojeb|website=Dailymotion|publisher=Navy ISPR|accessdate=22 November 2016|date=14 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122075004/http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x31ojeb|archive-date=2016-11-22|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> After the war, [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Richard Nixon]] forgave the remaining debt of ''Ghazi'' to Pakistan when the U.S. Navy's [[Chief of Naval Operations|CNO]] Admiral [[Elmo Zumwalt]] visited Admiral [[Mohammad Shariff]] in [[Calcutta]] in 1972.{{rp|219–226}}<ref name="roy" /> In addition, she remained the first and yet to-date the only U.S.-built submarine to have served in the Pakistan Navy, although in successive years, only [[Surface combatant|surface warships]] had been acquired through transfers from the United States as Pakistan worked towards building its own long-range submarines, the [[Agosta 90B class submarine|Agosta 90B]], through a [[technology transfer]] from France.<ref name="Defence Journal, General Lodhi">{{cite web|last1=Lodhi|first1=Lieutenant-General S.F.S.|title=An Agosta Submarine for Pakistan|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2000/jan/agosta.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=Defence Journal, General Lodhi|accessdate=22 November 2016|date=January 2000|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303193455/http://www.defencejournal.com/2000/jan/agosta.htm|archive-date=2016-03-03|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
At the [[Karachi Naval Dockyard|Naval Dockyard]] in [[Karachi]], a 'Ghazi Monument' was built to perpetuate the memory of the submarine and its 93 men.<ref name="Usman Shabbir, PakDef">{{cite web|last1=Shabbir|first1=Usman|title=Their Name Liveth for Ever More « PakDef Military Consortium|url=http://pakdef.org/their-name-liveth-for-ever-more/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180911081756/http://pakdef.org/their-name-liveth-for-ever-more/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 September 2018|website=pakdef.org|publisher=Usman Shabbir, PakDef|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref> In 1974, the naval base, {{ship|PNS|Zafar}}, was commissioned and constructed in the memory of Commander Zafar Muhammad Khan that now serves as the headquarter for [[Pakistan Navy Northern Command|Northern Naval Command]].<ref name="Usman Shabbir, PakDef"/> In 1975, the Navy acquired the {{sclass-|Albacora|submarine|2}} from the [[Portuguese Navy]] and named it ''Ghazi'' (S-134), in memory of PNS ''Ghazi''.<ref>See [[Albacora-class submarine]]</ref>
In 1998, the [[Inter-Services Public Relations]] produced and released the [[Television film|telefilm]], ''[[Ghazi Shaheed]]'' that [[Movie star|starred]] [[Shabbir Jan]] as commander of ''Ghazi'', and Mishi Khan as Commander's wife; the telefilm is based on the events involving ''Ghazi''{{'}}s mission and overlooks the lives of men who served in ''Ghazi''.<ref name="Ptv Classics">{{cite web|title=Ghazi Shaheed|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9oa8mtR5QnM|publisher=Ptv Classics|accessdate=20 November 2016|date=13 November 2015}}</ref> Another [[Pakistani films of 2015|movie]], ''Untold Stories: Ghazi and Hangor'' were sponsored and released by the ISPR to commemorate ''Ghazi'' and her crew during their missions in 1971.<ref name="Navy ISPR"/> In 2017, an Indian film was based on this submarine attack named ''[[The Ghazi Attack]]''.
In 2016, {{ship|PNS|Hameed}} was commissioned where ''Ghazi'' was honored and is a namesake of her [[First mate|first officer]], [[Lieutenant-Commander|Lt-Cdr.]] Pervez Hameed.<ref>Oversight [[PNS Zafar]]</ref>
===Notable commanders=== *Commander Gordon Graham Matheson–[[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] officer and her first commanding officer, commanded from 1945–1946.<ref>https://uboat.net/allies/commanders/3465.html</ref> *Commander [[Karamat Rahman Niazi]]– later appointed as the [[Four-star admiral|four-star]] rank admiral, commanded from 1964–66. *Commander [[Ahmed Tasnim]]– [[PNS Hangor|Hangor's]] commander in 1971 and later Vice-Admiral, commanded Ghazi from 1966–1969. *Lieutenant Commander Yousaf Raza– commanded Ghazi from 1969–1971 *Commander [[Zafar Muhammad Khan|Zafar Muhammad]]– the last commander until her sinking in 1971.
===Honors and awards===
<center> {| |align=center|{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=PAK Sitara-i-Juraat ribbon.svg|width=103}} | |align=center|{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Pride of Performance (ribbon).gif||width=103}} | |align=center|{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=Tamgha Jurat Ribbon.gif||width=103}} |- |align=center|[[Sitara-e-Jurat]]<br>{{small|(Awarded in 1965 and 1971)}} | |align=center|[[Pride of Performance|President's Citation]]<br>{{small|(Citation in 1965)}} | |align=center|[[Tamgha-i-Jurat]]<br>{{small|(Awarded in 1965)}} |} </center>
==In popular culture== * ''[[Ghazi Shaheed ]]'', a 1996 Pakistani telefilm describing the sumbarine's journey. * ''[[The Ghazi Attack]]'', a 2017 Indian film based on sinking of PNS Ghazi.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/interview-rana-daggubati-opens-up-about-first-film-on-indian-navy-ghazi-and-the-changing-indian-film-industry-2163210 |title=Rana Daggubati on India's first Navy film 'Ghazi' and changes in the film industry |work= |author=Latha Srinivasan |date=7 Jan 2016 |access-date=2018-05-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422085445/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/interview-rana-daggubati-opens-up-about-first-film-on-indian-navy-ghazi-and-the-changing-indian-film-industry-2163210 |archive-date=2016-04-22 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> * ''[[Raazi]]'' a 2018 Indian [[spy film|spy]] [[thriller film|thriller]] film directed by [[Meghna Gulzar]] about the Indian spy mission that provided intelligence about PNS Ghazi's mission to attack {{INS|Vikrant|R11|6}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timesnownews.com/entertainment/news/bollywood-news/article/is-alia-bhatts-raazi-an-unofficial-prequel-to-rana-daggubatis-the-ghazi-attack-heres-why-we-think-so/228445|title=Is Alia Bhatt's Raazi an unofficial prequel to Rana Daggubati's The Ghazi Attack? Here's why we think so|publisher=}}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Simple Things | image = | caption = | film name = {{Infobox name module|ru|Простые вещи}} | director = [[Alexei Popogrebski]] | writer = Alexei Popogrebski | starring = {{ubl|[[Sergei Puskepalis]]|[[Leonid Bronevoy]]}} | music = Dmitriy Katkhanov | cinematography = {{ubl|Pavel Kostomarov|Marina Gornostaeva}} | editing = | producer = | studio = Koktebel Film Company | released = 7 June 2007 | runtime = 115 minutes | country = Russia | language = Russian }} '''''Simple Things''''' ({{lang-ru|Простые вещи}}, [[Transliteration|translit.]] ''Prosty'e veshchi'') is a 2007 Russian [[comedy-drama]] film. Written and directed by [[Alexei Popogrebski]], the film stars [[Sergei Puskepalis]] and [[Leonid Bronevoy]].
The film was nominated for the [[Golden Eagle Award for Best Motion Picture (Russia)|Golden Eagle Award for Best Motion Picture]] and won Best Screenplay. Popogrebski and Bronevoy were also nominated for Best Director and Best Supporting Actor, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kinoacademy.ru/page/nominees-award-2007|script-title=ru:Номинанты Премии "Золотой Орел" за 2007 год|publisher=National Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences of Russia|accessdate=9 December 2017|trans-title=Nominees for the Prize "Golden Eagle Award" for 2007|language=Russian}}</ref> Bronevoy also won a [[Nika Award]] for Best Supporting Actor.
==Plot== A dying actor (Bronevoy) asks a doctor (Puskepalis) to help him [[Assisted suicide|commit suicide]] in exchange for a painting masterpiece.
==Cast== * [[Sergei Puskepalis]] as Sergei Maslov * [[Leonid Bronevoy]] as Zhuravlyov * Svetlana Kamynina as Katya * Dinara Kutuyevam as Lena * Ivan Osipov as Pyotr * Malkhaz Zhvaniya as Georgy
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|0846069}} * [http://2011.russiancinema.ru/index.php?e_dept_id=2&e_movie_id=18779 ''Simple Things'' (''Простые вещи'')] at russiancinema.ru {{ru icon}}
